How can one maintain dignity and grace in the face of unpleasant truths or conflicts within relationships?
How can we balance our curiosity to understand everything with the need to maintain harmony in our relationships?
How can we approach uncomfortable situations with a sense of nobility and respect for others?

header: lxxxix Know Yourself
content: —in talents and capacity, in judgment and inclination. You cannot master yourself unless you know yourself. There are mirrors for the face but none for the mind. Let careful thought about yourself serve as a substitute. [paragraph continues] When the outer image is forgotten, keep the inner one to improve and perfect. Learn the force of your intellect and capacity for affairs, test the force of your courage in order to apply it, and keep your foundations secure and your head clear for everything.
instructions: How can I gain a deeper understanding of my strengths and weaknesses to achieve personal growth?
What steps can I take to cultivate self-awareness and improve my decision-making abilities?
What practices can I adopt to maintain clarity in my goals and ensure I stay true to my inner values while navigating life's challenges?
How can I effectively evaluate my abilities and potential in order to navigate my personal and professional life with confidence?

header: xc The Secret of Long Life
content: Lead a good life. Two things bring life speedily to an end: folly and immorality. Some lose their life because they have not the intelligence to keep it, others because they have not the will. Just as virtue is its own reward, so is vice its own punishment. He who lives a fast life runs through life in a double sense. A virtuous life never dies. The firmness of the soul is communicated to the body, and a good life is long not only in intention but also in extension.
instructions: What advice would you give for living a long and fulfilling life?
What are the key principles for maintaining both physical health and moral integrity throughout one’s life?
What role do wisdom and personal values play in determining the longevity and quality of one's life?
What insights can you share about the connection between virtuous living and one's overall well-being and longevity?

header: xci Never set to work at anything if you have any doubts of its Prudence.
content: A suspicion of failure in the mind of the doer is proof positive of it in that of the onlooker, especially if he is a rival. If in the heat of action your judgment feels scruples, it will afterwards in cool reflection condemn it as a piece of folly. Action is dangerous where prudence is in doubt: better leave such things alone. Wisdom does not trust to probabilities; it always marches in the mid-day light of reason. How can an enterprise succeed which the judgment condemns as soon as conceived? And if resolutions passed nem. con. by inner court often turn out unfortunately, what can we expect of those undertaken by a doubting reason and a vacillating judgment?
instructions: What should I consider before committing to a new project if I'm feeling uncertain about its potential for success?
Is it wise to move forward with an idea when I have reservations about its feasibility?
How can I be sure that my instincts are guiding me correctly before I decide to take on a new challenge?
How can I overcome my doubts and make confident decisions when considering a risky venture?

header: xcii Transcendant Wisdom.
content: I mean in everything. The first and highest rule of all deed and speech, the more necessary to be followed the higher and more numerous our posts, is: an ounce of wisdom is worth more than tons of cleverness. It is the only sure way, though it may not gain so much applause. The reputation of wisdom is the last triumph of fame. It is enough if you satisfy the wise, for their judgment is the touchstone of true success.
instructions: What do you believe is more important for achieving long-term success: being clever or being wise?
How can one discern the true measure of success in life and leadership?
How do wisdom and cleverness play roles in making impactful decisions in our professional lives?
In a world that often values immediate recognition and applause, how can we cultivate a deeper appreciation for wisdom in our personal and professional journeys?

header: xciii Versatility.
content: A man of many excellences equals many men. By imparting his own enjoyment of life to his circle he enriches their life. Variety in excellences is the delight of life. It is a great art to profit by all that is good, and since Nature has made man in his highest development an abstract of herself, so let Art create in him a true microcosm by training his taste and intellect.
instructions: How can a person's diverse talents and interests enhance their relationships and overall enjoyment of life?
In what ways can we cultivate a rich and fulfilling life by embracing a variety of skills and qualities?
How can the pursuit of diverse skills and knowledge contribute to personal growth and the enrichment of our social circles?
How can developing a range of skills and qualities help us create a more enriching and vibrant community around us?

header: xciv Keep the extent of your Abilities unknown.
content: The wise man does not allow his knowledge and abilities to be sounded to the bottom, if he desires to be honoured by all. He allows you to know them but not to comprehend them. No one must know the extent of his abilities, lest he be disappointed. No one ever has an opportunity of fathoming him entirely. For guesses and doubts about the extent of his talents arouse more veneration than accurate knowledge of them, be they ever so great.
instructions: How can one achieve respect and admiration without revealing the full depth of their talents?
What strategies can one employ to maintain an aura of mystery around their skills and knowledge?
What is the importance of allowing others to perceive your skills without letting them fully understand their true extent?
What are the benefits of keeping your true abilities concealed in social or professional settings?

header: xcv Keep Expectation alive.
content: Keep stirring it up. Let much promise more, and great deeds herald greater. Do not rest your whole fortune on a single cast of the die. It requires great skill to moderate your forces so as to keep expectation from being dissipated.
instructions: How can I maintain motivation and hope when pursuing my goals?
What strategies can I use to manage my expectations while working towards significant accomplishments?
What can I do to ensure that my ambitions continue to inspire me toward greater achievements?
What advice can you offer on balancing patience and ambition while striving for success?

header: xcvi The highest Discretion.
content: It is the throne of reason, the foundation of prudence: by its means success is gained at little cost. It is a gift from above, and should be prayed for as the first and best quality. ’Tis the main piece of the panoply, and so important that its absence makes a man imperfect, whereas with other qualities it is merely a question of more or less. All the actions of life depend on its application; all require its assistance, for everything needs intelligence. Discretion consists in a natural tendency to the most rational course, combined with a liking for the surest.
instructions: What quality do you believe is most essential for achieving success and making wise decisions in life?
How can one cultivate the ability to make sound judgments that lead to effective decision-making in various aspects of life?
Why is discretion considered a vital attribute for navigating life's challenges and making thoughtful choices?
How do you define the role of discretion in the pursuit of personal and professional growth?

header: xcvii Obtain and preserve a Reputation.
content: It is the usufruct of fame. It is expensive to obtain a reputation, for it only attaches to distinguished abilities, which are as rare as mediocrities are common. Once obtained, it is easily preserved. It confers many an obligation, but it does more. When it is owing to elevated powers or lofty spheres of action, it rises to a kind of veneration and yields a sort of majesty. But it is only a well-founded reputation that lasts permanently.
instructions: What considerations should one keep in mind when trying to build and maintain a strong personal reputation in society?
How can one ensure that their reputation reflects genuine abilities and is not merely based on superficial qualities?
What strategies can one employ to cultivate a reputation that commands respect and influences others positively?
How can one cultivate a reputation that not only enhances personal standing but also inspires respect and admiration in others?

header: xcviii Write your Intentions in Cypher.
content: The passions are the gates of the soul. The most practical knowledge consists in disguising them. He that plays with cards exposed runs a risk of losing the stakes. The reserve of caution should combat the curiosity of inquirers: adopt the policy of the cuttlefish. Do not even let your tastes be known, lest others utilise them either by running counter to them or by flattering them.
instructions: How can I effectively manage my emotions and intentions so that others do not manipulate them?
In a world where everyone is constantly seeking to understand one another, how can I maintain my personal goals and desires without revealing too much to those around me?
How can I navigate social interactions without exposing my true motives and vulnerabilities?
How can I protect my inner thoughts and feelings from being misused by others in social situations?

header: xcix Reality and Appearance.
content: Things pass for what they seem, not for what they are. Few see inside; many take to the outside. It is not enough to be right, if right seem false and ill.  Footnotes
instructions: Is it possible for something to be true yet still be perceived as false by others?
How important is it for someone to appear credible, even if their true intentions or beliefs might be misunderstood?
How can we navigate a world where appearances often overshadow reality, and what should we prioritize: the truth of our actions or how they are perceived by others?
How do we discern the difference between who people truly are and how they choose to present themselves to the world?

header: c A Man without Illusions, a wise Christian, a philosophic Courtier.
content: Be all these, not merely seem to be them, still less affect to be them. Philosophy is nowadays discredited, but yet it was always the chiefest concern of the wise. The art of thinking has lost all its former repute. Seneca introduced it at Rome: it went to court for some time, but now it is considered out of place there. And yet the discovery of deceit was always thought the true nourishment of a thoughtful mind, the true delight of a virtuous soul.
instructions: What is the role of philosophy in today’s society, and how can one embody traits of wisdom and virtue in a world that often dismisses them?
How can one maintain authenticity and true understanding in a world that often values superficial appearances and shallow thinking?
How can we cultivate critical thinking and discernment in ourselves and others when the importance of true understanding and reflection seems to be undervalued in modern culture?
How can we navigate the complexities of modern life while staying grounded in genuine wisdom and avoiding the pitfalls of deception and pretense?

header: ci One half of the World laughs at the other, and Fools are they all.
content: Everything is good or everything is bad according to the votes they gain. What one pursues another persecutes. He is an in-sufferable ass that would regulate everything according to his ideas. Excellences do not depend on a single man's pleasure. So many men, so many tastes, all different. There is no defect which is not affected by some, nor need we lose heart if things please not some, for others will appreciate them. Nor need their applause turn our head, for there will surely be others to condemn. The real test of praise is the approbation of famous men and of experts in the matter. You should aim to be independent of any one vote, of any one fashion, of any one century.
instructions: Why should we care about others' opinions when it comes to defining value or excellence?
How can we navigate differing tastes and judgments in our pursuit of what is truly valuable or excellent?
Is it possible for something to be universally considered good or bad, or are we just reflecting our individual preferences?
How can we maintain our authenticity and avoid being swayed by the ever-changing opinions and trends around us?

header: cii Be able to stomach big slices of Luck.
content: In the body of wisdom not the least important organ is a big stomach, for great capacity implies great parts. Big bits of luck do not embarrass one who can digest still bigger ones. What is a surfeit for one may be hunger for another. Many are troubled as it were with weak digestion, owing to their small capacity being neither born nor trained for great employment. Their actions turn sour, and the humours that arise from their undeserved honours turn their head and they incur great risks in high place: they do not find their proper place, for luck finds no proper place in them. A man of talent therefore should show that he has more room for even greater enterprises, and above all avoid showing signs of a little heart.
instructions: How should one handle unexpected success and opportunities in life?
What qualities distinguish those who can rise to great challenges and take full advantage of fortune?
What mindset or character traits are necessary for an individual to effectively manage significant wealth and recognition?
How can one build the necessary resilience and capacity to manage significant achievements without being overwhelmed?

header: viii Let each keep up his Dignity.
content: Let each deed of a man in its degree, though he be not a king, be worthy of a prince, and let his action be princely within due limits. Sublime in action, lofty in thought, in all things like a king, at least in merit if not in might. For true kingship lies in spotless rectitude, and he need not envy greatness who can serve as a model of it. Especially should those near the throne aim at true superiority, and prefer to share the true qualities of royalty rather than take parts in its mere ceremonies, yet without affecting its imperfections but sharing in its true dignity.
instructions: How can individuals embody greatness and dignity in their everyday actions, even if they do not hold a position of power?
What does it mean to live with integrity and nobility, regardless of one's social status or recognition?
In what ways can someone demonstrate leadership qualities without holding a formal title or position?
How can striving for personal excellence and moral integrity transform the way we perceive and fulfill our roles in society, regardless of our titles or authority?

header: civ Try your hand at Office.
content: It requires varied qualities, and to know which is needed taxes attention and calls for masterly discernment. Some demand courage, others tact. Those that merely require rectitude are the easiest, the most difficult those requiring cleverness. For the former all that is necessary is character; for the latter all one's attention and zeal may not suffice. ’Tis a troublesome business to rule men, still more fools or blockheads: double sense is needed with those who have none. It is intolerable when an office engrosses a man with fixed hours and a settled routine. Those are better that leave a man free to follow his own devices, combining variety with importance, for the change refreshes the mind. The most in repute are those that have least or most distant dependence on others; the worst is that which worries us both here and hereafter.
instructions: What qualities should one cultivate to effectively navigate the complexities of leadership and office work?
What are the key challenges and considerations one should keep in mind when choosing a career that involves managing others?
What advice would you give to someone who is apprehensive about taking on a leadership role due to the demands and responsibilities it entails?
What insights can you offer about finding balance and fulfillment in a professional role that requires both creativity and structure?

header: cv Don't be a Bore.
content: The man of one business or of one topic is apt to be heavy. Brevity flatters and does better business; it gains by courtesy what it loses by curtness. Good things, when short, are twice as good. The quintessence of the matter is more effective than a whole farrago of details. It is a well-known truth that talkative folk rarely have much sense whether in dealing with the matter itself or its formal treatment. There are that serve more for stumbling-stones than centrepieces, useless lumber in every one's way. The wise avoid being bores, especially to the great, who are fully occupied: it is worse to disturb one of them than all the rest. Well said is soon said.
instructions: How can I effectively communicate my ideas without overwhelming my audience or wasting their time?
What advice do you have for making conversations more engaging and impactful without dragging them out?
How can I ensure that my interactions are respectful of others' time while still conveying my message clearly?
What strategies can I use to keep my discussions concise and interesting, especially when addressing busy individuals?

header: cvi Do not parade your Position.
content: To outshine in dignity is more offensive than in personal attractions. To pose as a personage is to be hated: envy is surely enough. The more you seek esteem the less you obtain it, for it depends on the opinion of others. You cannot take it, but must earn and receive it from others. Great positions require an amount of authority sufficient to make them efficient: without it they cannot be adequately filled. Preserve therefore enough dignity to carry on the duties of the office. Do not enforce respect, but try and create it. Those who insist on the dignity of their office, show they have not deserved it, and that it is too much for them. If you wish to be valued, be valued for your talents, not for anything adventitious. Even kings prefer to be honoured for their personal qualifications rather than for their station.
instructions: What is the best way to earn respect in a leadership role without relying on my title or position?
How can I cultivate a genuine sense of authority and dignity in my professional life without drawing attention to my title?
How can I demonstrate my worth as a leader without coming across as arrogant or overly authoritative?
How can I ensure that my leadership style inspires admiration rather than envy among my team?

header: cvii Show no Self-satisfaction.
content: You must neither be discontented with yourself—and that were poor-spirited—nor self-satisfied—and that is folly. Self-satisfaction arises mostly from ignorance: it would be a happy ignorance not without its advantages if it did not injure our credit. Because a man cannot achieve the superlative perfections of others, he contents himself with any mediocre talent of his own. Distrust is wise, and even useful, either to evade mishaps or to afford consolation when they come, for a misfortune cannot surprise a man who has already feared it. Even Homer nods at times, and Alexander fell from his lofty state and out of his illusions. Things depend on many circumstances: what constitutes triumph in one set may cause a defeat in another. In the midst of all incorrigible folly remains the same with empty self-satisfaction, blossoming, flowering, and running all to seed.
instructions: How can we balance self-confidence and humility in our pursuit of personal growth?
What are the dangers of being overly content with our achievements?
What should we be aware of when assessing our own abilities and achievements?
What mindset should we adopt to maintain a realistic view of our abilities while striving for excellence?

header: cviii The Path to Greatness is along with Others.
content: Intercourse works well: manners and taste are shared: good sense and even talent grow insensibly. Let the sanguine man then make a comrade of the lymphatic, and so with the other temperaments, so that without any forcing the golden mean is obtained. It is a great art to agree with others. The alternation of contraries beautifies and sustains the world: if it can cause harmony in the physical world, still more can it do so in the moral. Adopt this policy in the choice of friends and defendants; by joining extremes the more effective middle way is found.
instructions: How can we cultivate meaningful relationships that enhance our personal growth and understanding?
What strategies can we employ to foster collaboration and balance among diverse personalities in our social circles?
What insights can you offer on the importance of diversity in friendships and how it contributes to personal development and balance in our lives?
How can we effectively navigate our differences in temperament and perspectives to create a more harmonious and supportive community?

header: cix Be not Censorious.
content: There are men of gloomy character who regard everything as faulty, not from any evil motive but because it is their nature to. They condemn all: these for what they have done, those for what they will do. This indicates a nature worse than cruel, vile Indeed. They accuse with such exaggeration that they make out of motes beams wherewith to force out the eyes. They are always taskmasters who could turn a paradise into a prison; if passion intervenes they drive matters to the extreme. A noble nature, on the contrary, always knows how to find an excuse for failings, if not in the intention, at least from oversight.
instructions: Why do some people always seem to focus on the negatives in others, rather than understanding their flaws?
What drives some individuals to harshly judge others instead of showing empathy and understanding for their mistakes?
What can we learn about the impact of our judgments on others and the importance of compassion in our interactions?
What are the qualities of a person who is quick to criticize, and how do they differ from those who show kindness and understanding?

header: cx Do not wait till you are a Sinking Sun.
content: ’Tis a maxim of the wise to leave things before things leave them. One should be able to snatch a triumph at the end, just as the sun even at its brightest often retires behind a cloud so as not to be seen sinking, and to leave in doubt whether he has sunk or no. Wisely withdraw from the chance of mishaps, lest you have to do so from the reality Do not wait till they turn you the cold shoulder and carry you to the grave, alive in feeling but dead in esteem. Wise trainers put racers to grass before they arouse derision by falling on the course. A beauty should break her mirror early, lest she do so later with open eyes.
instructions: How can I gracefully exit a situation before it turns unfavorable?
What advice can you provide on recognizing when it's time to step back from a situation before it goes downhill?
What insights can you share about maintaining dignity and self-respect in the face of inevitable decline?
How can I ensure I leave a lasting positive impression before circumstances take a turn for the worse?

header: cxi Have Friends.
content: ’Tis a second existence. Every friend is good and wise for his friend: among them all everything turns to good. Every one is as others wish him; that they may wish him well, he must win their hearts and so their tongues. There is no magic like a good turn, and the way to gain friendly feelings is to do friendly acts. The most and best of us depend on others; we have to live either among friends or among enemies. Seek some one every day to be a well-wisher if not a friend; by and by after trial some of these will become intimate.
instructions: What is the significance of friendship in our lives, and how can we cultivate meaningful relationships with others?
How can the actions we take towards others influence the depth of our relationships and the support we receive in return?
What are the most effective ways to build trust and foster positive connections with others in our daily lives?
How can our daily interactions with others help us develop a supportive network of friends over time?

header: cxii Gain Good-will.
content: For thus the first and highest cause foresees and furthers the greatest objects. By gaining their good-will you gain men's good opinion. Some trust so much to merit that they neglect grace, but wise men know that Service Road without a lift from favour is a long way indeed. Good-will facilitates and supplies everything: is supposes gifts or even supplies them, as courage, zeal, knowledge, or even discretion; whereas defects it will not see because it does not search for them. It arises from some common interest, either material, as disposition, nationality, relationship, fatherland, office; or formal, which is of a higher kind of communion, in capacity, obligation, reputation, or merit. The whole difficulty is to gain good-will; to keep it is easy. It has, however, to be sought for, and, when found, to be utilised.
instructions: How can I build positive relationships and gain support from others in my personal and professional life?
What strategies can I employ to cultivate and maintain goodwill among my peers and colleagues?
What are the key factors that influence people's perception of me and my abilities, and how can I leverage those to create valuable connections?
What are the essential principles for winning people’s favor and ensuring lasting alliances in my endeavors?

header: cxiii In Prosperity prepare for Adversity.
content: It is both wiser and easier to collect winter stores in summer. In prosperity favours are cheap and friends are many. ’Tis well therefore to keep them for more unlucky days, for adversity costs dear and has no helpers. Retain a store of friendly and obliged persons; the day may come when their price will go up. Low minds never have friends; in luck they will not recognise them: in misfortune they will not be recognised by them.
instructions: What advice would you give on maintaining relationships during good times to prepare for potential hardships in the future?
How can one ensure they have a reliable support system when facing difficulties in life?
What strategies can one implement to cultivate meaningful connections and friendships while experiencing success?
How can someone recognize and appreciate the value of their friendships when life is going well, so they are not taken for granted when challenges arise?

header: cxiv Never Compete.
content: Every competition damages the credit: our rivals seize occasion to obscure us so as to out-shine us. Few wage honourable war. Rivalry discloses faults which courtesy would hide. Many have lived in good repute while they had no rivals. The heat of conflict gives life, or even new life, to dead scandals, and digs up long-buried skeletons. Competition begins with belittling, and seeks aid wherever it can, not only where it ought. And when the weapons of abuse do not effect their purpose, as often or mostly happens, our opponents use them for revenge, and use them at least for beating away the dust of oblivion from anything to our discredit. Men of good-will are always at peace; men of good repute and dignity are men of good-will.
instructions: What are the dangers of engaging in rivalry with others, and how can it affect one's reputation?
How can striving for superiority over others undermine our character and relationships?
What are the consequences of competing with others, and how does it impact our inner peace and the perception others have of us?
In what ways can avoidance of competition foster a more supportive and harmonious environment among individuals?

header: cxv Get used to the Failings of your Familiars,
content: as you do to ugly faces. It is indispensable if they depend on us, or we on them. There are wretched characters with whom one cannot live, nor yet without them. Therefore clever folk get used to them, as to ugly faces, so that they are not obliged to do so suddenly under the pressure of necessity. At first they arouse disgust, but gradually they lose this influence, and reflection provides for disgust or puts up with it.
instructions: How can we cope with difficult people in our lives without losing our peace of mind?
What strategies can we adopt to tolerate and manage our relationships with challenging individuals in our surroundings?
How can we develop resilience when dealing with the flaws of those close to us?
How can we cultivate patience and acceptance towards the imperfections of those we interact with regularly?

header: cxvi Only act with Honourable Men.
content: You can trust them and they you. Their honour is the best surety of their behaviour even in misunderstandings, for they always act having regard to what they are. Hence ’tis better to have a dispute with honourable people than to have a victory over dishonourable ones. You cannot treat with the ruined, for they have no hostages for rectitude. With them there is no true friendship, and their agreements are not binding, however stringent they may appear, because they have no feeling of honour. Never have to do with such men, for if honour does not restrain a man, virtue will not, since honour is the throne of rectitude.
instructions: Why is it important to surround ourselves with trustworthy and honorable people in our lives?
How can engaging with dishonorable individuals impact our own values and integrity?
What are the implications of choosing to interact with individuals who lack a sense of honor and integrity?
What qualities should we look for in our relationships to ensure they are meaningful and productive?

header: cxvii Never talk of Yourself.
content: You must either praise yourself, which is vain, or blame yourself, which is little-minded: it ill beseems him that speaks, and ill pleases him that hears. And if you should avoid this in ordinary conversation, how much more in official matters, and above all, in public speaking, where every appearance of unwisdom really is unwise. The same want of tact lies in speaking of a man in his presence, owing to the danger of going to one of two extremes: flattery or censure.
instructions: Why is it important to avoid discussing oneself in conversation, especially in public settings?
What are the potential consequences of someone talking about themselves in a group discussion or public speaking?
How can one navigate conversations about controversial topics without falling into self-promotion or criticism?
What strategies can one use to engage others in conversation without turning the focus back onto themselves?

header: cxviii Acquire the Reputation of Courtesy;
content: for it is enough to make you liked. Politeness is the main ingredient of culture,—a kind of witchery that wins the regard of all as surely as discourtesy gains their disfavour and opposition; if this latter springs from pride, it is abominable; if from bad breeding, it is despicable. Better too much courtesy than too little, provided it be not the same for all, which degenerates into injustice. Between opponents it is especially due as a proof of valour. It costs little and helps much: every one is honoured who gives honour. Politeness and honour have this advantage, that they remain with him who displays them to others.
instructions: How important is politeness and courtesy in establishing relationships and gaining respect in society?
What role does showing respect and courtesy play in enhancing one's character and reputation?
How can the practice of courtesy influence the dynamics between competitors or adversaries?
What are the benefits of consistently demonstrating politeness towards others, and how does it reflect on one's personal honor and reputation?

header: cxix Avoid becoming Disliked.
content: There is no occasion to seek dislike: it comes without seeking quickly enough. There are many who hate of their own accord without knowing the why or the how. Their ill-will outruns our readiness to please. Their ill-nature is more prone to do others harm than their cupidity is eager to gain advantage for themselves. Some manage to be on bad terms with all, because they always either produce or experience vexation of spirit. Once hate has taken root it is, like bad repute, difficult to eradicate. Wise men are feared, the malevolent are abhorred, the arrogant are regarded with disdain, buffoons with contempt, eccentrics with neglect. Therefore pay respect that you may be respected, and know that to be esteemed you must show esteem.
instructions: How can one avoid being disliked by others in social situations?
What are the traits or behaviors that lead to negative perceptions or dislike from others?
What strategies can we adopt to cultivate a positive reputation and foster goodwill in our relationships?
What are the consequences of harboring negative emotions towards others, and how can they affect our relationships?

header: cxx Live Practically.
content: Even knowledge has to be in the fashion, and where it is not it is wise to affect ignorance. Thought and taste change with the times. Do not be old-fashioned in your ways of thinking, and let your taste be in the modern style. In everything the taste of the many carries the votes; for the time being one must follow it in the hope of leading it to higher things. In the adornment of the body as of the mind adapt yourself to the present, even though the past appear better. But this rule does not apply to kindness, for goodness is for all time. It is neglected nowadays and seems out of date. Truth-speaking, keeping your word, and so too good people, seem to come from the good old times: yet they are liked for all that, but in such a way that even when they all exist they are not in the fashion and are not imitated. What a misfortune for our age that it regards virtue as a stranger and vice as a matter of course! If you are wise, live as you can, if you cannot live as you would. Think more highly of what fate has given you than of what it has denied.
instructions: How can we navigate the pressures of societal expectations while staying true to our values and principles?
In a world where trends seem to shift rapidly, how can we maintain our integrity and wisdom without conforming to fleeting fads?
How can we balance our desire for personal authenticity with the need to adapt to changing social norms and expectations?
How can we reconcile the importance of personal virtues with the reality that society often celebrates superficiality and vice?

header: cxxi Do not make a Business of what is no Business.
content: As some make gossip out of everything, so others business. They always talk big, take everything in earnest, and turn it into a dispute or a secret. Troublesome things must not be taken too seriously if they can be avoided. It is preposterous to take to heart that which you should throw over your shoulders. Much that would be something has become nothing by being left alone, and what was nothing has become of consequence by being made much of. At the outset things can be easily settled, but not afterwards. Often the remedy causes the disease. ’Tis by no means the least of life's rules: to let things alone.
instructions: How should we approach trivial conflicts or gossip in our daily lives?
What advice do you have for managing situations where people tend to overreact or blow things out of proportion?
How can we better discern which challenges deserve our attention and which we should simply let go?
What strategies can we employ to maintain our peace of mind in the face of unnecessary drama or complications?

header: cxxii Distinction in Speech and Action.
content: By this you gain a position in many places and carry esteem beforehand. It shows itself in everything, in talk, in look, even in gait. It is a great victory to conquer men's hearts: it does not arise from any foolish presumption or pompous talk, but in a becoming tone of authority born of superior talent combined with true merit.
instructions: How can one effectively gain respect and influence in social and professional situations?
What qualities and behaviors contribute to establishing a strong presence and credibility among peers?
What are the key elements that elevate one's communication style and personal demeanor to foster admiration and gather support from others?
What strategies can one adopt to naturally express authority and foster admiration through both their words and actions?

header: cxxiii Avoid Affectation.
content: The more merit, the less affectation, which gives a vulgar flavour to all. It is wearisome to others and troublesome to the one affected, for he becomes a martyr to care and tortures himself with attention. The most eminent merits lose most by it, for they appear proud and artificial instead of being the product of nature, and the natural is always more pleasing than the artificial. One always feels sure that the man who affects a virtue has it not. The more pains you take with a thing, the more should you conceal them, so that it may appear to arise spontaneously from your own natural character. Do not, however, in avoiding affectation fall into it by affecting to be unaffected. The sage never seems to know his own merits, for only by not noticing them can you call others' attention to them. He is twice great who has all the perfections in the opinion of all except of himself; he attains applause by two opposite paths.
instructions: How can I ensure that my achievements and qualities are appreciated by others without coming across as arrogant or insincere?
What advice would you give on balancing confidence in my abilities without seeming pretentious or forced?
What strategies can I use to present my strengths authentically without drawing negative attention to myself?
How can I express my individuality and strengths without coming off as try-hard or artificial?

header: cxxiv Get Yourself missed.
content: Few reach such favour with the many; if with the wise ’tis the height of happiness. When one has finished one's work, coldness is the general rule. But there are ways of earning this reward of goodwill. The sure way is to excel in your office and talents: add to this agreeable manner and you reach the point where you become necessary to your office, not your office to you. Some do honour to their post, with others ’tis the other way. It is no great gain if a poor successor makes the predecessor seem good, for this does not imply that the one is missed, but that the other is wished away.
instructions: How can one ensure they are truly valued and missed in their position or role?
What qualities or actions contribute to making someone indispensable in their role?
What strategies can be employed to leave a lasting positive impact in a professional role?
What does it take to cultivate a strong reputation and ensure that others recognize your contributions in a role?

header: cxxv Do not be a Black List.
content: It is a sign of having a tarnished name to concern oneself with the ill-fame of others. Some wish to hide their own stains with those of others, or at least wash them away: or they seek consolation therein—’tis the consolation of fools. They must have bad breath who form the sewers of scandal for the whole town. The more one grubs about in such matters, the more one befouls oneself. There are few without stain somewhere or other, but it is of little known people that the failings are little known. Be careful then to avoid being a registrar of faults. That is to be an abominable thing, a man that lives without a heart.
instructions: Why do some people seem to take pleasure in spreading rumors and highlighting the faults of others?
What are the dangers of getting involved in gossip and criticizing others?
Is there a moral obligation to overlook others' mistakes in order to maintain one's integrity and character?
How can focusing on the shortcomings of others impact our own character and reputation?

header: cxxvi Folly consists not in committing Folly, but in not hiding it when committed.
content: You should keep your desires sealed up, still more your defects. All go wrong sometimes, but the wise try to hide the errors, but fools boast of them. Reputation depends more on what is hidden than on what is done; if a man does not live chastely, he must live cautiously. The errors of great men are like the eclipses of the greater lights. Even in friendship it is rare to expose one's failings to one's friend. Nay, one should conceal them from oneself if one can. But here one can help with that other great rule of life: learn to forget.
instructions: Is it important to showcase our flaws, or should we focus on maintaining a positive image in society?
How can we navigate our mistakes and maintain our reputation in a world that often criticizes vulnerability?
Is it better to admit our shortcomings or to present ourselves in a more favorable light to others?
How should we manage our imperfections and mistakes in a society that values appearances over authenticity?

header: cxxvii Grace in Everything.
content: ’Tis the life of talents, the breath of speech, the soul of action, and the ornament of ornament. Perfections are the adornment of our nature, but this is the adornment of perfection itself. It shows itself even in the thoughts. ’Tis most a gift of nature and owes least to education; it even triumphs over training. It is more than ease, approaches the free and easy, gets over embarrassment, and adds the finishing touch to perfection. Without it beauty is lifeless, graciousness ungraceful: it surpasses valour, discretion, prudence, even majesty it-self. ’Tis a short way to dispatch and an easy escape from embarrassment.
instructions: What is the significance of grace in personal interactions and accomplishments?
How does grace enhance the qualities of talent and character in our actions and communication?
How does grace contribute to our overall presence and effectiveness in social situations and decision-making?
How does grace influence the way we perceive and react to beauty and excellence in ourselves and others?

header: cxxviii Highmindedness.
content: One of the principal qualifications for a gentleman, for it spurs on to all kinds of nobility. It improves the taste, ennobles the heart, elevates the mind, refines the feelings, and intensifies dignity. It raises him in whom it is found, and at times remedies the bad turns of Fortune, which only raises by striking. It can find full scope in the will when it cannot be exercised in act. Magnanimity, generosity, and all heroic qualities recognise in it their source.
instructions: What qualities define true nobility and how do they influence a person's character and actions?
How does highmindedness contribute to personal growth and the development of a gentleman's virtues?
In what ways does highmindedness shape one's response to adversity and the challenges posed by life?
How does highmindedness enhance a person's dignity and influence their interactions with others in society?

header: cxxix Never complain.
content: To complain always brings discredit. Better be a model of self-reliance opposed to the passion of others than an object of their compassion. For it opens the way for the hearer to what we are complaining of, and to disclose one insult forms an excuse for another. By complaining of past offences we give occasion for future ones, and in seeking aid or counsel we only obtain indifference or contempt. It is much more politic to praise one man's favours, so that others may feel obliged to follow suit. To recount the favours we owe the absent is to demand similar ones from the present, and thus we sell our credit with the one to the other. The shrewd will therefore never publish to the world his failures or his defects, but only those marks of consideration which serve to keep friendship alive and enmity silent.
instructions: What advice would you give on how to handle negative experiences or setbacks in a way that maintains your dignity and relationships with others?
What strategies can we employ to maintain our reputation and avoid unnecessary sympathy when facing challenges or disappointments?
What wisdom can you share about the impact of complaining on personal relationships and how it affects others' perceptions of us?
How can we effectively foster strong and supportive relationships without inviting pity or judgment from others when we encounter difficulties?

header: cxxx Do and be seen Doing.
content: Things do not pass for what they are but for what they seem. To be of use and to know how to show yourself of use, is to be twice as useful. What is not seen is as if it was not. Even the Right does not receive proper consideration if it does not seem right. The observant are far fewer in number than those who are deceived by appearances. Deceit rules the roast, and things are judged by their jackets, and many things are other than they seem. A good exterior is the best recommendation of the inner perfection.
instructions: How important is it to craft our public image in relation to our true abilities and character?
How can we ensure that our true contributions and value are recognized in a world focused on appearances?
What strategies can we employ to make our positive qualities and efforts more visible to others in a society that often prioritizes surface impressions?
How can we effectively navigate a landscape where perception often overshadows reality in our personal and professional lives?

header: cxxxi Nobility of Feeling.
content: There is a certain distinction of the soul, a highmindedness prompting to gallant acts, that gives an air of grace to the whole character. It is not found often, for it presupposes great magnanimity. Its chief characteristic is to speak well of an enemy, and to act even better to-wards him. It shines brightest when a chance comes of revenge: not alone does it let the occasion pass, but it improves it by using a complete victory in order to display unexpected generosity. ’Tis a fine stroke of policy, nay, the very acme of statecraft. It makes no pretence to victory, for it pretends to nothing, and while obtaining its deserts it conceals its merits.
instructions: What does true nobility of character look like in the face of conflict or rivalry?
How can one elevate their character through acts of kindness, even towards those who have wronged them?
How can demonstrating grace and generosity towards one's adversaries enhance one’s personal integrity and reputation?
How can demonstrating exceptional kindness in the face of adversity reflect our inner strength and wisdom?

header: cxxxii Revise your Judgments.
content: To appeal to an inner Court of Revision makes things safe. Especially when the course of action is not clear, you gain time either to confirm or improve your decision. It affords new grounds for strengthening or corroborating your judgment. And if it is a matter of giving, the gift is the more valued from its being evidently well considered than for being promptly bestowed: long expected is highest prized. And if you have to deny, you gain time to decide how and when to mature the No that it may be made palatable. Besides, after the first heat of desire is passed the repulse of refusal is felt less keenly in cold blood. But especially when men press for a reply is it best to defer it, for as often as not that is only a feint to disarm attention.
instructions: How should I handle situations where I'm pressured to make a quick decision or give an immediate answer?
What strategies can I use to ensure my judgments are well considered before acting?
When faced with a difficult choice, how can I ensure that my final decision is thoughtful and not impulsive?
What are the benefits of taking time to reflect before responding to requests or making decisions?

header: cxxxiii Better Mad with the rest of the World than Wise alone.
content: So say politicians. If all are so, one is no worse off than the rest, whereas solitary wisdom passes for folly. So important is it to sail with the stream. The greatest wisdom often consists in ignorance, or the pretence of it. One has to live with others, and others are mostly ignorant. "To live entirely alone one must be very like a god or quite like a wild beast," but I would turn the aphorism by saying: Better be wise with the many than a fool all alone. There be some too who seek to be original by seeking chimeras.
instructions: Is it better to conform to societal norms even if it means sacrificing personal wisdom, or should one embrace solitude and remain true to their knowledge?
Is it really more valuable to blend in with the crowd than to stand out alone with one's insight?
Is wisdom truly recognized and appreciated only when it aligns with the beliefs of the majority, or can it stand strong even when faced with societal ignorance?
Is it possible that wisdom is undervalued in a society that often prioritizes conformity over individual insight?

header: cxxxiv Double your Resources.
content: You thereby double your life. One must not depend on one thing or trust to only one resource, however pre-eminent. Everything should be kept double, especially the causes of success, of favour, or of esteem. The moon's mutability transcends everything and gives a limit to all existence, especially of things dependent on human will, the most brittle of all things. To guard against this inconstancy should be the sage's care, and for this the chief rule of life is to keep a double store of good and useful qualities. Thus as Nature gives us in duplicate the most important of our limbs and those most exposed to risk, so Art should deal with the qualities on which we depend for success.
instructions: What advice would you give for ensuring success and stability in an unpredictable world?
How can we best prepare ourselves for the uncertainties of life and avoid relying too heavily on a single source of strength or support?
How can we cultivate resilience and adaptability in our lives to manage the ever-changing nature of success and fortune?
How can we effectively build a diverse set of skills and qualities to ensure our continued growth and success amidst life's unpredictability?

header: cxxxv Do not nourish the Spirit of Contradiction.
content: It only proves you foolish or peevish, and prudence should guard against this strenuously. To find difficulties in everything may prove you clever, but such wrangling writes you down a fool. Such folk make a mimic war out of the most pleasant conversation, and in this way act as enemies towards their associates rather than towards those with whom they do not consort. Grit grates most in delicacies, and so does contradiction in amusement. They are both foolish and cruel who yoke together the wild beast and the tame.
instructions: Why do some people seem to enjoy arguing and contradicting others, even in friendly discussions?
What are the consequences of constantly challenging others' opinions in social situations?
What advice can you give on maintaining harmony in conversations when disagreements arise?
What strategies can one adopt to engage in conversations that foster understanding instead of conflict?

header: cxxxvi Post Yourself in the Centre of Things.
content: So you feel the pulse of affairs. Many lose their way either in the ramifications of useless discussion or in the brushwood of wearisome verbosity without ever realising the real matter at issue. They go over a single point a hundred times, wearying themselves and others, and yet never touch the all-important centre of affairs. This comes from a confusion of mind from which they cannot extricate themselves. They waste time and patience on matters they should leave alone, and cannot spare them afterwards for what they have left alone.
instructions: How can I effectively focus my efforts and avoid getting lost in irrelevant discussions when trying to solve complex issues?
What strategies can I use to ensure I concentrate on the core issues rather than getting sidetracked by insignificant details during discussions?
How can I cultivate the ability to discern what truly matters in my conversations and decision-making processes?
What are some techniques I can employ to maintain clarity of thought and stay focused on the key points during debates or discussions?

header: cxxxvii The Sage should be Self-sufficing.
content: He that was all in all to himself carried all with him when he carried himself. If a universal friend can represent to us Rome and the rest of the world, let a man be his own universal friend, and then he is in a position to live alone. Whom could such a man want if there is no clearer intellect or finer taste than his own? He would then depend on himself alone, which is the highest happiness and like the Supreme Being. He that can live alone resembles the brute beast in nothing, the sage in much and God in everything.
instructions: How can one achieve true happiness and self-sufficiency in life?
What qualities make a person truly independent and capable of thriving on their own?
What does it mean to be truly self-reliant and how can that lead to a deeper understanding of oneself?
What role does self-sufficiency play in developing a strong sense of personal identity and wisdom?

header: cxxxviii The Art of letting Things alone.
content: The more so the wilder the waves of public or of private life. There are hurricanes in human affairs, tempests of passion, when it is wise to retire to a harbour and ride at anchor. Remedies often make diseases worse: in such cases one has to leave them to their natural course and the moral suasion of time. It takes a wise doctor to know when not to prescribe, and at times the greater skill consists in not applying remedies. The proper way to still the storms of the vulgar is to hold your hand and let them calm down of themselves. To give way now is to conquer by and by. A fountain gets muddy with but little stirring up, and does not get clear by our meddling with it but by our leaving it alone. The best remedy for disturbances is to let them run their course, for so they quiet down.
instructions: How should we respond to chaotic situations in life without overreacting or interfering unnecessarily?
What is the best approach to managing conflict or turmoil in our personal relationships?
What is the wisdom in knowing when to step back and let situations resolve themselves?
What insights can you offer on the importance of patience and restraint when dealing with crises or emotional turbulence?

header: cxxxix Recognise unlucky Days.
content: They exist: nothing goes well on them; even though the game may be changed the ill-luck remains. Two tries should be enough to tell if one is in luck to-day or not. Everything is in process of change, even the mind, and no one is always wise: chance has something to say, even how to write a good letter. All perfection turns on the time; even beauty has its hours. Even wisdom fails at times by doing too much or too little. To turn out well a thing must be done on its own day. This is why with some everything turns out ill, with others all goes well, even with less trouble. They find everything ready, their wit prompt, their presiding genius favourable, their lucky star in the ascendant. At such times one must seize the occasion and not throw away the slightest chance. But a shrewd person will not decide on the day's luck by a single piece of good or bad fortune, for the one may be only a lucky chance and the other only a slight annoyance.
instructions: How can I determine if today is a good day to take risks or make important decisions?
What should I consider when evaluating whether to seize an opportunity or hold back based on my current situation?
How can I understand the importance of timing in achieving success and making the right choices?
What are some signs that I might be experiencing a streak of bad luck, and how can I navigate through it effectively?

header: cxl Find the Good in a Thing at once.
content: ’Tis the advantage of good taste. The bee goes to the honey for her comb, the serpent to the gall for its venom. So with taste: some seek the good, others the ill. There is nothing that has no good in it, especially in books, as giving food for thought. But many have such a scent that amid a thousand excellences they fix upon a single defect, and single it out for blame as if they were scavengers of men's minds and hearts. So they draw up a balance sheet of defects which does more credit to their bad taste than to their intelligence. They lead a sad life, nourishing themselves on bitters and battening on garbage. They have the luckier taste who midst a thousand defects seize upon a single beauty they may have hit upon by chance.
instructions: Why is it important to focus on the positive aspects of things instead of just pointing out their flaws?
How can we cultivate a mindset that appreciates the hidden values in people or things, rather than fixating on their shortcomings?
In a world filled with negativity and criticism, how can one develop the ability to discern and appreciate the inherent goodness in various situations or individuals?
How can we train ourselves to recognize the potential for goodness in everything we encounter, even when it seems overshadowed by flaws?

header: cxli Do not listen to Yourself.
content: It is no use pleasing yourself if you do not please others, and as a rule general contempt is the punishment for self-satisfaction. The attention you pay to yourself you probably owe to others. To speak and at the same time listen to yourself cannot turn out well. If to talk to oneself when alone is folly, it must be doubly unwise to listen to oneself in the presence of others. It is a weakness of the great to talk with a recurrent "as I was saying" and "eh?" which bewilders their hearers. At every sentence they look for applause or flattery, taxing the patience of the wise. So too the pompous speak with an echo, and as their talk can only totter on with the aid of stilts, at every word they need the support of a stupid "bravo!"
instructions: Why do some people seem so absorbed in seeking validation from others when expressing their thoughts?
Is it possible that focusing too much on our own thoughts can hinder our ability to connect with others effectively?
How can individuals strike a balance between self-expression and being considerate of how their words impact others?
How can the need for external approval in conversation undermine genuine communication and understanding?

header: cxlii Never from Obstinacy take the Wrong Side because your Opponent has anticipated you in taking the Right One.
content: You begin the fight already beaten and must soon take to flight in disgrace. With bad weapons one can never win. It was astute in the opponent to seize the better side first: it would be folly to come lagging after with the worst. Such obstinacy is more dangerous in actions than in words, for action encounters more risk than talk. ’Tis the common failing of the obstinate that they lose the true by contradicting it, and the useful by quarrelling with it. The sage never places himself on the side of passion, but espouses the cause of right, either discovering it first or improving it later. If the enemy is a fool, he will in such a case turn round to follow the opposite and worse way. Thus the only way to drive him from the better course is to take it yourself, for his folly will cause him to desert it, and his obstinacy be punished for so doing.
instructions: What should I do when I strongly disagree with someone who seems to be on the right track?
What should I consider when I'm tempted to stubbornly defend my position, even when I realize my opponent has valid points?
Is it ever wise to stick to my viewpoint just for the sake of being different, even if it seems less reasonable than my opponent's perspective?
How do I know when it's better to change my mind rather than defend a position that might be wrong?

header: cxliii Never become Paradoxical in order to avoid the Trite.
content: Both extremes damage our reputation. Every undertaking which differs from the reasonable approaches foolishness. The paradox is a cheat: it wins applause at first by its novelty and piquancy, but afterwards it becomes discredited when the deceit is fore-seen and its emptiness becomes apparent. It is a species of jugglery, and in matters political would be the ruin of states. Those who cannot or dare not reach great deeds on the direct road of excellence go round by way of Paradox, admired by fools but making wise men true prophets. It argues an unbalanced judgment, and if it is not altogether based on the false, it is certainly founded on the uncertain, and risks the weightier matters of life.
instructions: Is trying to stand out in a unique way always beneficial, or can it lead to misunderstandings and loss of credibility?
Is it wise to embrace unconventional ideas or behaviors solely for the sake of differentiation, or can this approach ultimately backfire?
Is there a risk in pursuing original ideas if they stray too far from accepted norms, potentially leading to a loss of trust and respect from others?
Is it possible that seeking attention through provocative or extreme opinions might ultimately undermine one's integrity and reliability in the eyes of others?

header: cxliv Begin with Another's to end with your Own.
content: ’Tis a politic means to your end. Even in heavenly matters Christian teachers lay stress on this holy cunning. It is a weighty piece of dissimulation, for the foreseen advantages serve as a lure to influence the other's will. His affair seems to be in train when it is really only leading the way for another's. One should never advance unless under cover, especially where the ground is dangerous. Likewise with persons who always say No at first, it is useful to ward off this blow, because the difficulty of conceding much more does not occur to them when your version is presented to them. This advice belongs to the rule about second thoughts [xiii], which covers the most subtle manœuvres of life.
instructions: How can I effectively persuade someone who is initially resistant to my ideas without directly confronting their objections?
What strategies can I use to navigate complex negotiations where I need to consider others' interests while still achieving my own goals?
What techniques can I employ to subtly influence someone's decision-making while ensuring my own objectives are met?
What are some clever ways to guide someone towards a decision that ultimately benefits me, especially when they are initially closed off to new ideas?

header: cxlv Do not show your wounded Finger,
content: for everything will knock up against it; nor complain about it, for malice always aims where weakness can be injured. It is no use to be vexed: being the butt of the talk will only vex you the more. Ill-will searches for wounds to irritate, aims darts to try the temper, and tries a thousand ways to sting to the quick. The wise never own to being hit, or disclose any evil, whether personal or hereditary. For even Fate sometimes likes to wound us where we are most tender. It always mortifies wounded flesh. Never therefore disclose the source of mortification or of joy, if you wish the one to cease, the other to endure.
instructions: How can I protect myself from others exploiting my vulnerabilities or weaknesses?
How can I stay resilient and maintain my composure when others try to provoke me by targeting my sensitivities?
How should I handle my personal struggles so that others don't use them against me?
How can I navigate social situations without letting my insecurities become a target for criticism?

header: cxlvi Look into the Interior of Things.
content: Things are generally other than they seem, and ignorance that never looks beneath the rind becomes disabused when you show the kernel. Lies always come first, dragging fools along by their irreparable vulgarity. Truth always lags last, limping along on the arm of Time. The wise therefore reserve for it the other half of that power which the common mother has wisely given in duplicate. Deceit is very superficial, and the superficial therefore easily fall into it. Prudence lives retired within its recesses, visited only by sages and wise men.
instructions: What advice would you offer on how to distinguish between appearances and deeper truths in life?
How can one cultivate discernment in a world full of deception and superficiality?
What insights can you share about the nature of truth and its relationship with time and wisdom?
In a society where many people are quick to accept things at face value, how can one develop a deeper understanding of reality beyond surface appearances?

header: cxlvii Do not be Inaccessible.
content: None is so perfect that he does not need
instructions: Why is it important to remain approachable and open to others, even when one is successful or knowledgeable?
What is the significance of humility and accessibility in fostering genuine connections with others?
How can being open and relatable contribute to personal growth and understanding in our interactions with others?
Why is vulnerability important in building trust and meaningful relationships with others?

header: cxlviii Have the Art of Conversation.
content: That is where the real personality shows itself. No act in life requires more attention, though it be the commonest thing in life. You must either lose or gain by it. If it needs care to write a letter which is but a deliberate and written conversation, how much more the ordinary kind in which there is occasion for a prompt display of intelligence? Experts feel the pulse of the soul in the tongue, wherefore the sage said, "Speak, that I may know thee." Some hold that the art of conversation is to be without art—that it should be neat, not gaudy, like the garments. This holds good for talk between friends. But when held with persons to whom one would show respect, it should be more dignified to answer to the dignity of the person addressed. To be appropriate it should adapt itself to the mind and tone of the interlocutor. And do not be a critic of words, or you will be taken for a pedant; nor a taxgatherer of ideas, or men will avoid you, or at least sell their thoughts dear. in conversation discretion is more important than eloquence.
instructions: What makes a conversation meaningful and impactful in our interactions with others?
How can we improve our conversational skills to connect better with others?
What role does the tone and respect for the other person's status play in effective communication?
How important is authenticity versus artifice in our everyday conversations?

header: cxlix Know how to put off Ills on Others.
content: To have a shield against ill-will is a great piece of skill in a ruler. It is not the resort of incapacity, as ill-wishers imagine, but is due to the higher policy of having some one to receive the censure of the disaffected and the punishment of universal detestation. Everything cannot turn out well, nor can every one be satisfied: it is well therefore, even at the cost of our pride, to have such a scapegoat, such a target for unlucky undertakings.
instructions: How can leaders effectively manage criticism and blame in challenging situations?
What strategies should a leader employ to deflect negativity and maintain their own reputation during tough times?
What techniques can leaders use to navigate public dissatisfaction while preserving their own standing?
What methods can leaders adopt to ensure accountability without taking personal blame in the face of adversity?

header: cl Know to get your Price for Things.
content: Their intrinsic value is not sufficient; for all do not bite at the kernel or look into the interior. Most go with the crowd, and go because they see others go. It is a great stroke of art to bring things into repute; at times by praising them, for praise arouses desire at times by giving them a striking name, which is very useful for putting things at a premium, provided it is done without affectation. Again, it is generally an inducement to profess to supply only connoisseurs, for all think themselves such, and if not, the sense of want arouses the desire. Never call things easy or common: that makes them depreciated rather than made accessible. All rush after the unusual, which is more appetising both for the taste and for the intelligence.
instructions: How can I make my skills and talents more valuable in today's competitive world?

What techniques can I use to create a sense of exclusivity and demand for something that might otherwise be overlooked?
What methods can I employ to effectively elevate the appeal and desirability of ordinary items or experiences?

header: cli Think beforehand.
content: To-day for to-morrow, and even for many days hence. The greatest foresight consists in determining beforehand the time of trouble. For the provident there are no mischances and for the careful no narrow escapes. We must not put off thought till we are up to the chin in mire. Mature reflection can get over the most formidable difficulty. The pillow is a silent Sibyl, and it is better to sleep on things beforehand than lie awake about them afterwards. Many act first and then think afterwards—that is, they think less of consequences than of excuses: others think neither before nor after. The whole of life should be one course of thought how not to miss the right path. Rumination and foresight enable one to determine the line of life.
instructions: What advice can you offer on how to effectively navigate life's challenges and make better decisions?
How can I develop a mindset that prepares me for future difficulties and helps me avoid making hasty decisions?
How can I cultivate the habit of thinking ahead to prevent problems before they arise?
How can I learn to prioritize reflection and foresight in my daily life to improve my decision-making skills?

header: clii Never have a Companion who casts you in the Shade.
content: The more he does so, the less desirable a companion he is. The more he excels in quality the more in repute: he will always play first fiddle and you second. If you get any consideration, it is only his leavings. The moon shines bright alone among the stars: when the sun rises she becomes either invisible or imperceptible. Never join one that eclipses you, but rather one who sets you in a brighter light. By this means the cunning Fabula in Martial was able to appear beautiful and brilliant, owing to the ugliness and disorder of her companions. But one should as little imperil oneself by an evil companion as pay honour to another at the cost of one's own credit. When you are on the way to fortune associate with the eminent; when arrived, with the mediocre.
instructions: How important is it to choose the right friends and associates in order to succeed in life?
What should I consider when deciding who to surround myself with in my personal and professional life?
How can I ensure that the people I spend time with enhance my own potential and success rather than diminish it?
What qualities should I look for in my friends to ensure that they uplift and inspire me rather than overshadow my own abilities?

header: cliii Beware of entering where there is a great Gap to be filled.
content: But if you do it be sure to surpass your predecessor; merely to equal him requires twice his worth. As it is a fine stroke to arrange that our successor shall cause us to be wished back, so it is policy to see that our predecessor does not eclipse us. To fill a great gap is difficult, for the past always seems best, and to equal the predecessor is not enough, since he has the right of first possession. You must therefore possess additional claims to oust the other from his hold on public opinion.
instructions: What advice would you give someone stepping into a role or position that has been previously held by a highly respected figure?
How can one successfully navigate the challenges of following someone who left a significant impact in their position?
What strategies would you recommend for someone taking over a leadership role after a predecessor who has set a very high standard?
What insights can you share on how to build a strong reputation and unique identity when stepping into a position where you've got big shoes to fill?

header: cliv Do not Believe, or Like, lightly.
content: Maturity of mind is best shown in slow belief. Lying is the usual thing; then let belief be unusual. He that is lightly led away, soon falls into contempt. At the same time there is no necessity to betray your doubts in the good faith of others, for this adds insult to discourtesy, since you make out your informant to be either deceiver or deceived. Nor is this the only evil: want of belief is the mark of the liar, who suffers from two failings: he neither believes nor is believed. Suspension of judgment is prudent in a hearer: the speaker can appeal to his original source of in-formation. There is a similar kind of imprudence in liking too easily, for lies may be told by deeds as well as in words, and this deceit is more dangerous for practical life.
instructions: Why should we be cautious about trusting people too quickly?
How can we develop the skill of discerning truthfulness in both words and actions without becoming overly cynical?
In a world filled with misinformation and deception, how can we cultivate a mindset that allows us to evaluate information critically without becoming paralyzed by doubt?
How can we protect ourselves from being misled by others while maintaining healthy relationships and open communication?

header: clv The Art of getting into a Passion.
content: If possible, oppose vulgar importunity with prudent reflection; it will not be difficult for a really prudent man. The first step towards getting into a passion is to announce that you are in a passion. By this means you begin the conflict with command over your temper, for one has to regulate one's passion to the exact point that is necessary and no further. This is the art of arts in falling into and getting out of a rage. You should know how and when best to come to a stop: it is most difficult to halt while running at the double. It is a great proof of wisdom to remain clear-sighted during paroxysms of rage. Every excess of passion is a digression from rational conduct. But by this masterly policy reason will never be transgressed, nor pass the bounds of its own synteresis. To keep control of passion one must hold firm the reins of attention: he who can do so will be the first man "wise on horseback," and probably the last.
instructions: How can I effectively manage my emotions and avoid losing control during conflict situations?
What techniques can I use to remain calm and composed when I feel anger rising in me?
What strategies can I adopt to express my anger constructively without allowing it to spiral out of control?
What insights can you share about the balance between recognizing and expressing anger while maintaining rationality?

header: clvi Select your Friends.
content: Only after passing the matriculation of experience and the examination of fortune will they be graduates not alone in affection but in discernment. Though this is the most important thing in life, it is the one least cared for. Intelligence brings friends to some, chance to most. Yet a man is judged by his friends, for there was never agreement between wise men and fools. At the same time, to find pleasure in a man's society is no proof of near friendship: it may come from the pleasantness of his company more than from trust in his capacity. There are some friendships legitimate, others illicit; the latter for pleasure, the former for their fecundity of ideas and motives. Few are the friends of a man's self, most those of his circumstances. The insight of a true friend is more useful than the goodwill of others: therefore gain them by choice, not by chance. A wise friend wards off worries, a foolish one brings them about. But do not wish them too much luck, or you may lose them.
instructions: How should we go about selecting friends who truly enrich our lives?
What qualities should we look for in friendships to ensure they contribute positively to our growth and well-being?
What considerations should we keep in mind when evaluating the depth and authenticity of our friendships?
What are the key differences between genuine friendships and those based solely on convenience or circumstance?

header: civil Do not make Mistakes about Character.
content: That is the worst and yet easiest error. Better be cheated in the price than in the quality of goods. In dealing with men, more than with other things, it is necessary to look within. To know men is different from knowing things. It is profound philosophy to sound the depths of feeling and distinguish traits of character. Men must be studied as deeply as books.
instructions: How can we better understand people's true character and avoid being misled in our interactions with them?
What strategies can we use to discern authenticity in people's actions and intentions?
What are the key qualities we should look for in others to assess their true nature and ensure we form meaningful connections?
What insights can you share about the importance of inner qualities versus outward appearances when choosing whom to trust or associate with?

header: clviii Make use of your Friends.
content: This requires all the art of discretion. Some are good afar off, some when near. Many are no good at conversation but excellent as correspondents, for distance removes some failings which are unbearable in close proximity to them. Friends are for use even more than for pleasure, for they have the three qualities of the Good, or, as some say, of Being in general: unity, goodness, and truth. For a friend is all in all. Few are worthy to be good friends, and even these become fewer because men do not know how to pick them out. To keep is more important than to make friends. Select those that will wear well; if they are new at first, it is some consolation they will become old. Absolutely the best are those well salted, though they may require soaking in the testing. There is no desert like living without friends. Friendship multiplies the good of life and divides the evil. ’Tis the sole remedy against misfortune, the very ventilation of the soul.
instructions: How can we effectively choose and nurture friendships that will benefit our lives in the long run?
What insights can you share about the deeper value and role of friendship in navigating life's challenges?
What advice can you give on the qualities that distinguish a true friend from a mere acquaintance?
What strategies can we employ to maintain friendships that bring us joy and support during difficult times?

header: clix Put up with Fools.
content: The wise are always impatient, for he that increases knowledge increase impatience of folly. Much knowledge is difficult to satisfy.
