The first great rule of life, according to Epictetus, is to put up with things: he makes that the moiety of wisdom. To put up with all the varieties of folly would need much patience. We often have to put up with most from those on whom we most depend: a useful lesson in self-control. Out of patience comes forth peace, the priceless boon which is the happiness of the world. But let him that bath no power of patience retire within himself, though even there he will have to put up with himself.
instructions: How can we find peace and patience in a world filled with foolishness and those who frustrate us?
What strategies can we use to maintain our composure when dealing with people whose actions we find foolish or infuriating?
How can we develop the ability to tolerate the foolishness of others without losing our sense of inner peace?
What can we learn about handling frustration when we encounter foolishness in those around us?

header: clx Be careful in Speaking.
content: With your rivals from prudence; with others for the sake of appearance. There is always time to add a word, never to withdraw one. Talk as if you were making your will: the fewer words the less litigation. In trivial matters exercise yourself for the more weighty matters of speech. Profound secrecy has some of the lustre of the divine. He who speaks lightly soon falls or fails.
instructions: What advice would you give on how to communicate effectively and avoid misunderstandings in difficult conversations?
What strategies can you share for maintaining discretion and thoughtfulness when engaging in conversations with others?
What principles should one follow to ensure that their words hold weight and are impactful in both personal and professional interactions?
What insights can you offer on the importance of being mindful of our speech in order to cultivate respect and credibility in our relationships?

header: clxi Know your pet Faults.
content: The most perfect of men has them, and is either wedded to them or has illicit relations with them. They are often faults of intellect, and the greater this is, the greater they are, or at least the more conspicuous. It is not so much that their possessor does not know them: he loves them, which is a double evil: irrational affection for avoidable faults. They are spots on perfection; they displease the onlooker as much as they please the possessor. ’Tis a gallant thing to get clear of them, and so give play to one's other qualities. For all men hit upon such a failing, and on going over your qualifications they make a long stay at this blot, and blacken it as deeply as possible in order to cast your other talents into the shade.
instructions: What advice would you give for identifying and overcoming personal flaws that might overshadow our strengths?
Why do you think some individuals become attached to their own weaknesses, despite knowing they hinder their growth and reputation?
What do you believe is the impact of recognizing our personal shortcomings on our overall development and how we are perceived by others?
How can recognizing and understanding our personal shortcomings lead to greater personal growth and better relationships with others?

header: clxii How to triumph over Rivals and Detractors.
content: It is not enough to despise them, though this is often wise: a gallant bearing is the thing. One cannot praise a man too much who speaks well of them who speak ill of him. There is no more heroic vengeance than that of talents and services which at once conquer and torment the envious. Every success is a further twist of the cord round the neck of the ill-affected, and an enemy's glory is the rival's hell. The envious die not once, but as oft as the envied wins applause. The immortality of his fame is the measure of the other's torture: the one lives in endless honour, the other in endless pain. The clarion of Fame announces immortality to the one and death to the other, the slow death of envy long drawn out.
instructions: How can someone effectively deal with jealousy from their rivals or detractors while still achieving success?
What strategies can a person use to turn the negativity from envious peers into motivation and personal growth?
What insights can you share about the relationship between one's achievements and the reactions of competitors who harbor envy?
What can one do to maintain grace and poise in the face of envy, while simultaneously using their achievements to rise above negativity?

header: clxiii Never, from Sympathy with the Unfortunate, involve Yourself in his Fate.
content: One man's misfortune is another man's luck, for one cannot be lucky without many being unlucky. It is a peculiarity of the unfortunate to arouse people's goodwill who desire to compensate them for the blows of fortune with their useless favour, and it happens that one who was abhorred by all in prosperity is adored by all in adversity. Vengeance on the wing is exchanged for compassion afoot. Yet ’tis to be noticed how fate shuffles the cards. There are men who always consort with the unlucky, and he that yesterday flew high and happy stands to-day miserable at their side. That argues nobility of soul, but not worldly wisdom.
instructions: Is it wise to get involved in the struggles of someone who is facing misfortune?
How do we balance empathy for those who are suffering without risking our own well-being?
How can we maintain our own success while supporting those who are experiencing hardship?
Given the complexities of human relationships, how should we approach offering support to those who are down on their luck without letting their struggles drag us down as well?

header: clxiv Throw Straws in the Air,
content: to find how things will be received, especially those whose reception or success is doubtful. One can thus be assured of its turning out well, and an opportunity is afforded for going on in earnest or withdrawing entirely. By trying men's intentions in this way, the wise man knows on what ground he stands. This is the great rule of foresight in asking, in desiring, and in ruling.
instructions: How can I effectively gauge people's reactions to my ideas before fully committing to them?
What strategies can I use to test the waters when making decisions that might not be well received?
How can I strategically assess the potential impact of my proposals on others before investing significant time and resources into them?
What are some effective ways to evaluate the likelihood of success for my plans before fully pursuing them?

header: clxv Wage War Honourably.
content: You may be obliged to wage war, but not to use poisoned arrows. Every one must needs act as he is, not as others would make him to be. Gallantry in the battle of life wins all men's praise: one should fight so as to conquer, not alone by force but by the way it is used. A mean victory brings no glory, but rather disgrace. Honour always has the upper hand. An honourable man never uses forbidden weapons, such as using a friendship that's ended for the purposes of a hatred just begun: a confidence must never be used for a vengeance. The slightest taint of treason tarnishes the good name. In men of honour the smallest trace of meanness repels: the noble and the ignoble should be miles apart. Be able to boast that if gallantry, generosity, and fidelity were lost in the world men would be able to find them again in your own breast.
instructions: What does it mean to fight honorably in personal conflicts and how can one maintain integrity while facing challenges?
How can one navigate betrayal and conflict in relationships while still preserving their honor and dignity?
How can one ensure that their actions in challenging situations reflect true nobility and do not compromise their values?
What principles should guide someone in their approach to overcoming adversity while ensuring their actions remain just and honorable?

header: clxvi Distinguish the Man of Words from the Man of Deeds.
content: Discrimination here is as important as in the case of friends, persons, and employments, which have all many varieties. Bad words even without bad deeds are bad enough: good words with bad deeds are worse. One cannot dine off words, which are wind, nor off politeness, which is but polite deceit. To catch birds with a mirror is the ideal snare. It is the vain alone who take their wages in windy words. Words should be the pledges of work, and, like pawn-tickets, have their market price. Trees that bear leaves but not fruit have usually no pith. Know them for what they are, of no use except for shade.
instructions: How can we differentiate between people who only speak well and those who actually follow through with their actions?
What should we consider when evaluating someone's integrity and reliability beyond just their words?
How can we ensure that the promises made by others are backed by real intentions and actions?
How can we tell if someone is genuinely committed to their promises, or if they're just skillful at using language to manipulate perceptions?

header: clxvii Know how to take your own Part.
content: In great crises there is no better companion than a bold heart, and if it becomes weak it must be strengthened from the neighbouring parts. Worries die away before a man who asserts himself. One must not surrender to misfortune, or else it would become intolerable. Many men do not help themselves in their troubles, and double their weight by not knowing how to bear them. He that knows himself knows how to strengthen his weakness, and the wise man conquers everything, even the stars in their courses.
instructions: How can we effectively cope with overwhelming challenges and ensure that we don’t let adversity defeat us?
What strategies can we use to build our inner strength and resilience during difficult times?
What insights can you share on the importance of self-awareness in overcoming personal struggles and setbacks?
What practical advice would you give on how to maintain courage and determination in the face of life's struggles?

header: clxviii Do not indulge in the Eccentricities of Folly.
content: Like vain, presumptuous, egotistical, untrustworthy, capricious, obstinate, fanciful, theatrical, whimsical, inquisitive, paradoxical, sectarian people and all kinds of one-sided persons: they are all monstrosities of impertinence. All deformity of mind is more obnoxious than that of the body, because it contravenes a higher beauty. Yet who can assist such a complete confusion of mind? Where self-control is wanting, there is no room for others' guidance. Instead of paying attention to other people's real derision, men of this kind blind themselves with the unfounded assumption of their imaginary applause.
instructions: What are the dangers of allowing one's ego and eccentricities to dictate their actions and perceptions?
How can we recognize and overcome the influence of our own irrational beliefs and quirks that lead us away from genuine self-awareness?
What strategies can we implement to avoid becoming overly self-absorbed and disconnected from the reality and perceptions of others?
How can we cultivate the ability to see ourselves clearly and understand how our unconventional behaviors may alienate us from others?

header: clxix Be more careful not to Miss once than to Hit a hundred times.
content: No one looks at the blazing sun; all gaze when he is eclipsed. The common talk does not reckon what goes right but what goes wrong. Evil report carries farther than any applause. Many men are not known to the world till they have left it. All the exploits of a man taken together are not enough to wipe out a single small blemish. Avoid therefore falling into error, seeing that ill-will notices every error and no success.
instructions: How can I effectively manage my reputation in a world that seems to focus more on my mistakes than my successes?
How can I ensure my efforts and achievements are recognized and valued rather than overshadowed by my failures?
How can I navigate criticism and maintain my self-worth in a society that often highlights my missteps over my accomplishments?
What strategies can I adopt to minimize the impact of my mistakes and emphasize my strengths in a judgmental environment?

header: clxx In all Things keep Something in Reserve.
content: ’Tis a sure means of keeping up your importance. [paragraph continues] A man should not employ all his capacity and power at once and on every occasion. Even in knowledge there should be a rearguard, so that your resources are doubled. One must always have something to resort to when there is fear of a defeat. The reserve is of more importance than the attacking force: for it is distinguished for valour and reputation. Prudence always sets to work with assurance of safety: in this matter the piquant paradox holds good that the half is more than the whole.
instructions: How can I maintain my influence and effectiveness in challenging situations without overextending myself?
What strategies can I use to ensure I remain prepared and resourceful in the face of uncertainty or potential setbacks?
What advice do you have for managing one’s talents and abilities in a way that preserves strength for future challenges?
How can I cultivate a sense of confidence and resilience by strategically reserving my energy and resources for future opportunities?

header: clxxi Waste not Influence.
content: The great as friends are for great occasions. One should not make use of great confidence for little things: for that is to waste a favour. The sheet anchor should be reserved for the last extremity. If you use up the great for little ends what remains afterwards? Nothing is more valuable than a protector, and nothing costs more nowadays than a favour. It can make or unmake a whole world. It can even give sense and take it away. As Nature and Fame are favourable to the wise, so Luck is generally envious of them. It is therefore more important to keep the favour of the mighty than goods and chattels.
instructions: How should we best manage our relationships and favors in challenging situations to ensure we don’t deplete our valuable connections?
How can we wisely navigate the use of our influential connections in everyday situations without overextending them?
How can we ensure we are utilizing our influential contacts wisely without draining their support for trivial matters?
What strategies can we employ to prioritize our influential relationships and reserve their support for truly significant moments?

header: clxxii Never contend with a Man who has nothing to Lose;
content: for thereby you enter into an unequal conflict. The other enters without anxiety; having lost everything, including shame, he has no further loss to fear. He therefore re-sorts to all kinds of insolence. One should never expose a valuable reputation to so terrible a risk, lest what has cost years to gain may be lost in a moment, since a single slight may wipe out much sweat. A man of honour and responsibility has a reputation, because he has much to lose. He balances his own and the other's reputation: he only enters into the contest with the greatest caution, and then goes to work with such circumspection that he gives time to prudence to retire in time and bring his reputation under cover. For even by victory he cannot gain what he has lost by exposing himself to the chances of loss.
instructions: What advice would you give on dealing with confrontations when the other party has no stakes to lose?
How should one approach conflicts with individuals who seem indifferent to consequences?
How should one protect their reputation when faced with someone who has nothing left to lose?
What strategies can one use to navigate situations where the opposing side appears reckless and uninhibited due to having nothing to lose?

header: clxxiii Do not be Glass in Intercourse, still less in Friendship.
content: Some break very easily, and thereby show their want of consistency. They attribute to themselves imaginary offences and to others oppressive intentions. Their feelings are even more sensitive than the eye itself, and must not be touched in jest or in earnest. Motes offend them: they need not wait for beams. Those who consort with them must treat them with the greatest delicacy, have regard to their sensitiveness, and watch their demeanour, since the slightest slight arouses their annoyance. They are mostly very egoistic, slaves of their moods, for the sake of which they cast everything aside: they are the worshippers of punctilio. On the other hand, the disposition of the true lover is firm and enduring, so that it may be said that the Arrant is half adamant.
instructions: What advice would you give about maintaining healthy relationships with emotionally sensitive individuals?
How can one differentiate between genuine friendship and ties that are easily fractured by emotional sensitivity?
What insights can you share about the qualities of a resilient friendship compared to one that is overly fragile due to emotional sensitivity?
How do emotional sensitivities in friendships affect interpersonal dynamics and the ability to navigate conflicts?

header: clxxiv Do not live in a Hurry.
content: To know how to separate things is to know how to enjoy them. Many finish their fortune sooner than their life: they run through pleasures without enjoying them, and would like to go back when they find they have over-leaped the mark. Postilions of life, they increase the ordinary pace of life by the hurry of their own calling. They devour more in one day than they can digest in a whole life-time; they live in advance of pleasures, eat up the years beforehand, and by their hurry get through everything too soon. Even in the search for knowledge there should be moderation, lest we learn things better left unknown. We have more days to live through than pleasures. Be slow in enjoyment, quick at work, for men see work ended with pleasure, pleasure ended with regret.
instructions: How can we find balance between enjoying life’s pleasures and pursuing our goals without rushing through our experiences?
What advice can you give about savoring experiences in a world that encourages constant speed and productivity?
What wisdom can you share about the dangers of haste in both pleasure and the quest for knowledge, and how can we cultivate a mindset of patience?
What insights do you have on how the relentless pace of modern life affects our ability to truly appreciate and absorb our experiences?

header: clxxv A Solid Man.
content: One who is finds no satisfaction in those that are not. ’Tis a pitiable eminence that is not well founded. Not all are men that seem to be so. Some are sources of deceit; impregnated by chimeras they give birth to impositions. Others are like them so far that they take more pleasure in a lie, because it promises much, than in the truth, because it performs little. But in the end these caprices come to a bad end, for they have no solid foundation. Only Truth can give true reputation: only reality can be of real profit. One deceit needs many others, and so the whole house is built in the air and must soon come to the ground. Unfounded things never reach old age. They promise too much to be much trusted, just as that cannot be true which proves too much.
instructions: What qualities should we look for in people to ensure that we can trust them and rely on their integrity?
How can we distinguish between genuine individuals and those who are merely pretending to be trustworthy?
What characteristics differentiate a true leader from one who simply presents a façade of competence and honesty?
What does it mean to have a solid foundation in one's character and how does it contribute to long-lasting credibility?

header: clxxvi Have Knowledge, or know those that have Knowledge.
content: Without intelligence, either one's own or another's, true life is impossible. But many do not know that they do not know, and many think they know when they know nothing. Failings of the intelligence are incorrigible, since those who do not know, do not know themselves, and cannot therefore seek what they lack. Many would be wise if they did not think themselves wise. Thus it happens that though the oracles of wisdom are rare, they are rarely used. To seek advice does not lessen greatness or argue incapacity. On the contrary, to ask advice proves you well advised. Take counsel with reason it you do not wish to court defeat.
instructions: Why is it important to seek knowledge and advice from others when making decisions in life?
How can one recognize their own limitations in understanding and make better choices in life?
How can we differentiate between true wisdom and the illusion of knowledge in our everyday lives?
What role does self-awareness play in the pursuit of knowledge and the ability to make sound decisions?

header: clxxvii Avoid Familiarities in Intercourse.
content: Neither use them nor permit them. He that is familiar, loses any superiority his Influence gives him, and so loses respect. The stars keep their brilliance by not making themselves common. The Divine demands decorum. Every familiarity breeds contempt. In human affairs, the more a man shows, the less he has, for in open communication you communicate the failings that reserve might keep under cover. Familiarity is never desirable; with superiors because it is dangerous, with inferiors because it is unbecoming, least of all with the common herd, who become insolent from sheer folly: they mistake favour shown them for need felt of them. Familiarity trenches on vulgarity.
instructions: What are the dangers of being too familiar with people in positions of power or authority?
How can maintaining a level of decorum in our relationships enhance our personal influence and respect within social circles?
What are the potential pitfalls of becoming too casual or intimate in social interactions?
How can we balance approachability with maintaining respect in our relationships with others?

header: clxxviii Trust your Heart,
content: especially when it has been proved. Never deny it a hearing. It is a kind of house oracle that often foretells the most important. Many have perished because they feared their own heart, but of what use is it to fear it without finding a better remedy? Many are endowed by Nature with a heart so true that it always warns them of misfortune and wards off its effects. It is unwise to seek evils, unless you seek to conquer them.
instructions: How can we learn to trust our instincts and intuition when making important decisions?
What advice would you give to someone who struggles to listen to their inner voice and often second-guesses their feelings?
What wisdom can you share about the value of listening to one's emotions when facing difficult choices?
What insights can you provide on the importance of recognizing and understanding our true feelings, especially in moments of uncertainty?

header: clxxix Reticence is the Seal of Capacity.
content: A breast without a secret is an open letter. Where there is a solid foundation secrets can be kept profound: there are spacious cellars where things of moment may be hid. Reticence springs from self-control, and to control oneself in this is a true triumph. You must pay ransom to each you tell. The security of wisdom consists in temperance in the inner man. The risk that reticence runs lies in the cross-questioning of others, in the use of contradiction to worm out secrets, in the darts of irony: to avoid these the prudent become more reticent than before. What must be done need not be said, and what must be said need not be done.
instructions: How important is it to keep certain thoughts and feelings private in order to maintain personal strength and wisdom?
What role does discretion play in building trust and maintaining strong relationships with others?
What is the significance of being selective about what you choose to share with others, and how does that reflect on your strength of character?
How can exercising restraint in what we reveal about ourselves influence our personal and professional interactions?

header: clxxx Never guide the Enemy to what he has to do.
content: The fool never does what the wise judge wise, because he does not follow up the suitable means. He that is discreet follows still less a plan laid out, or even carried out, by another. One has to discuss matters from both points of view—turn it over on both sides. Judgments vary; let him that has not decided attend rather to what is possible than what is probable.
instructions: How can one effectively navigate and strategize in complex situations without falling into the traps laid by others?
What principles should guide our decision-making process when faced with conflicting opinions and potential distractions from others?
How can we make sound decisions when challenged by external influences that may cloud our judgment?
What are the best practices for evaluating options and making decisions independently, especially when others might influence the situation?

header: clxxxi The Truth, but not the whole Truth.
content: Nothing demands more caution than the truth: ’tis the lancet of the heart. It requires as much to tell the truth as to conceal it. [paragraph continues] A single lie destroys a whole reputation for integrity. The deceit is regarded as treason and the deceiver as a traitor, which is worse. Yet not all truths can be spoken: some for our own sake, others for the sake of others.
instructions: What are the complexities of being honest in relationships and communication?
How do we navigate the balance between transparency and discretion when sharing truths that may hurt others?
How can one determine which truths are essential to share and which should be withheld for the greater good?
Is it ever justifiable to remain silent about certain truths to protect someone's feelings, and how do we decide when silence may be more virtuous than honesty?

header: clxxxii A Grain of Boldness in Everything.
content: ’Tis an important piece of prudence. You must moderate your opinion of others so that you may not think so high of them as to fear them. The imagination should never yield to the heart. Many appear great till you know them personally, and then dealing with them does more to disillusionise than to raise esteem. No one o’ersteps the narrow bounds of humanity: all have their weaknesses either in heart or head. Dignity gives apparent authority, which is rarely accompanied by personal power: for Fortune often redresses the height of office by the inferiority of the holder. The imagination always jumps too soon, and paints things in brighter colours than the real: it thinks things not as they are but as it wishes them to be. Attentive experience disillusionised in the past soon corrects all that. Yet if wisdom should not be timorous, neither should folly be rash. [paragraph continues] And if self-reliance helps the ignorant, how much more the brave and wise?
instructions: How can we balance our perceptions of others with the reality of their character to avoid false admiration?
What insights can you share on the relationship between our expectations of people in power and their actual capabilities?
How can we cultivate a more realistic understanding of ourselves and others to avoid disillusionment and enable personal growth?
What advice do you have for developing the courage to approach others without being intimidated by their status or reputation?

header: clxxxiii Do not hold your Views too firmly.
content: Every fool is fully convinced, and every one fully persuaded is a fool: the more erroneous his judgment the more firmly he holds it. Even in cases of obvious certainty, it is fine to yield: our reasons for holding the view cannot escape notice, our courtesy in yielding must be the more recognised. Our obstinacy loses more than our victory yields: that is not to champion truth but rather rudeness. There be some heads of iron most difficult to turn: add caprice to obstinacy and the sum is a wearisome fool. Steadfastness should be for the will, not for the mind. Yet there are exceptions where one would fail twice, owning oneself wrong both in judgment and in the execution of it.
instructions: Why is it important to remain open-minded in discussions and debates, even when we strongly believe in our perspective?
How can we balance our convictions with the need to be flexible in our thinking when faced with new information or differing opinions?
What advice would you give to someone who struggles to change their opinions, even when presented with strong evidence against them?
How can maintaining a stance that is too rigid hinder our personal growth and understanding of the world?

header: clxxxiv Do not be Ceremonious.
content: Even in a king affectation in this was renowned for its eccentricity. To be punctilious is to be a bore, yet whole nations have this peculiarity. The garb of folly is woven out of such things. Such folk are worshippers of their own dignity, yet show how little it is justified since they fear that the least thing can destroy it. It is right to demand respect, but not to be considered a master of ceremonies. Yet it is true that a man to do without ceremonies must possess supreme qualities. Neither affect nor despise etiquette: he cannot be great who is great at such little things.
instructions: What is your perspective on the importance of social etiquette and formality in personal and societal interactions?
How can we balance the need for respect in social interactions with the desire to be genuine and authentic, without getting caught up in unnecessary formalities?
What are your thoughts on how excessive formality can hinder genuine connections between people?
How do you define true greatness in a person, and do you believe that adhering to social rituals and ceremonies diminishes or enhances one's character?

header: clxxxv Never stake your Credit on a single Cast;
content: for if it miscarries the damage is irreparable. It may easy happen that a man should fail once, especially at first: circumstances are not always favourable: hence they say, "Every dog has his day." Always connect your second attempt with your first: whether it succeed or fail, the first will redeem the second. Always have resort to better means and appeal to more resources. Things depend on all sorts of chances. That is why the satisfaction of success is so rare.
instructions: What advice would you give about taking risks and handling failure in life?
How can I ensure that I learn from my setbacks and increase my chances of future success?
What strategies can I use to improve my chances of success when facing uncertain outcomes?
What insights can you share about the importance of diversifying one's efforts in pursuit of goals?

header: clxxxvi Recognise Faults, however high placed.
content: Integrity cannot mistake vice even when clothed in brocade or perchance crowned with gold, but will not be able to hide its character for all that. Slavery does not lose its vileness, however it vaunt the nobility of its lord and master. Vices may stand in high place, but are low for all that. Men can see that many a great man has great faults, yet they do not see that he is not great because of them. The example of the great is so specious that it even glosses over viciousness, till it may so affect those who flatter it that they do not notice that what they gloss over in the great they abominate in the lower classes.
instructions: What are your thoughts on how society often overlooks the faults of those in power while criticizing the same flaws in others?
How do you define true greatness in a person, especially when they hold significant power or status?
How do you think our perceptions of morality change when we encounter people who hold influential positions or wealth?
What do you believe is the impact of social status on people's ability to recognize and confront the flaws in those who hold power?

header: clxxxvii Do pleasant Things Yourself, unpleasant Things through Others.
content: By the one course you gain goodwill, by the other you avoid hatred. A great man takes more pleasure in doing a favour than in receiving one: it is the privilege of his generous nature. One cannot easily cause pain to another without suffering pain either from sympathy or from remorse. In high place one can only work by means of rewards and punishment, so grant the first yourself, inflict the other through others. Have some one against whom the weapons of discontent, hatred, and slander may be directed. For the rage of the mob is like that of a dog: missing the cause of its pain it turns to bite the whip itself, and though this is not the real culprit, it has to pay the penalty.
instructions: How can a leader effectively manage the perception of their actions while maintaining goodwill among their followers?
How should one navigate the complexities of leadership to promote positive relationships while delegating the responsibility for difficult decisions?
What strategies can someone in a position of power use to maintain a positive image while ensuring that they are not directly blamed for unpopular decisions?
How can someone in a position of authority balance the need to make tough choices while preserving their reputation and fostering loyalty among their team?

header: clxxxviii Be the Bearer of Praise.
content: This increases our credit for good taste, since it shows that we have learnt elsewhere to know what is excellent, and hence how to prize it in the present company. It gives material for conversation and for imitation, and encourages praiseworthy exertions. We do homage besides in a very delicate way to the excellences before us. Others do the opposite; they accompany their talk with a sneer, and fancy they flatter those present by belittling the absent. This may serve them with superficial people, who do not notice how cunning it is to speak ill of every one to every one else. Many pursue the plan of valuing more highly the mediocrities of the day than the most distinguished exploits of the past. Let the cautious penetrate through these subtleties, and let him not be dismayed by the exaggerations of the one or made over-confident by the flatteries of the other; knowing that both act in the same way by different methods, adapting their talk to the company they are in.
instructions: How should we approach conversations about others when trying to uplift our social interactions?
What are the best practices for recognizing and appreciating the achievements of others in a way that enhances our own character and social interactions?
What advice can you give on how to foster a positive and respectful environment in social settings when discussing the accomplishments of others?
What strategies can we use to encourage a culture of genuine admiration and respect for achievements in our social circles, rather than resorting to backhanded compliments or false modesty?

header: clxxxix Utilise Another's Wants.
content: The greater his wants the greater the turn of the screw. Philosophers say privation is non-existent, statesmen say it is all-embracing, and they are right. Many make ladders to attain their ends out of wants of others. They make use of the opportunity and tantalise the appetite by pointing out the difficulty of satisfaction. The energy of desire promises more than the inertia of possession. The passion of desire increases with every increase of opposition. It is a subtle point to satisfy the desire and yet preserve the dependence.
instructions: How can understanding the desires and needs of others help one achieve their own goals in life?
What strategies can one employ to effectively navigate and leverage the desires of others to create mutually beneficial outcomes?
How can recognizing and manipulating the unfulfilled desires of others enhance one's influence in personal or professional relationships?
What insights can you share about the dynamics of desire and dependence in influencing the behavior of others?

header: cxc Find Consolation in all Things.
content: Even the useless may find it in being immortal. No trouble without compensation. Fools are held to be lucky, and the good-luck of the ugly is proverbial. Be worth little and you will live long: it is the cracked glass that never gets broken, but worries one with its durability. It seems that Fortune envies the great, so it equalises things by giving long life to the use-less, a short one to the important. Those who bear the burden come soon to grief, while those who are of no importance live on and on: in one case it appears so, in the other it is so. The unlucky thinks he has been for-gotten by both Death and Fortune.
instructions: Why do some people seem to live long lives without ever achieving greatness or making a significant impact?
What is the relationship between worth and longevity in life?
Is there a hidden wisdom in the idea that sometimes the seemingly insignificant people or things endure longer than those that are deemed important?
What can we learn about the nature of value and the perception of success in life, considering that some who contribute little still seem to endure?

header: cxci Do not take Payment in Politeness;
content: for it is a kind of fraud. Some do not need the herbs of Thessaly for their magic, for they can enchant fools by the grace of their salute. Theirs is the Bank of Elegance, and they pay with the wind of fine words. To promise everything is to promise nothing: promises are the pitfalls of fools. The true courtesy is performance of duty: the spurious and especially the useless is deceit. It is not respect but rather a means to power. Obeisance is paid not to the man but to his means, and compliments are offered not to the qualities that are recognised but to the advantages that are desired.
instructions: Is politeness always genuine, or can it sometimes be used as a tool for manipulation?
Can outward expressions of respect and courtesy be deceptive, serving hidden agendas rather than genuine goodwill?
How can we identify when someone's courteous behavior is sincere versus when it is simply a tactic to gain influence?
How can we discern the difference between true respect and mere flattery in our interactions with others?

header: cxcii Peaceful Life, a long Life.
content: To live, let live. Peacemakers not only live: they rule life. Hear, see, and be silent. A day without dispute brings sleep without dreams. Long life and a pleasant one is life enough for two: that is the fruit of peace. He has all that makes nothing of what is nothing to him. There is no greater perversity than to take everything to heart. There is equal folly in troubling our heart about what does not concern us and in not taking to heart what does.
instructions: What insights can you share about the relationship between peace and a fulfilling life?
How can we cultivate inner calm and resilience in the face of external conflicts?
How can we avoid unnecessary conflicts and focus on what truly matters in our daily lives?
What wisdom can you provide on the importance of emotional detachment in maintaining personal peace and wellbeing?

header: cxciii Watch him that begins with Another's to end with his own.
content: Watchfulness is the only guard against cunning. Be intent on his intentions. Many succeed in making others do their own affairs, and unless you possess the key to their motives you may at any moment be forced to take their chestnuts out of the fire to the damage of your own fingers.
instructions: How can we better protect ourselves from being manipulated by others in their schemes?
What strategies can we employ to discern others' true intentions and avoid becoming pawns in their plans?
What are some signs that someone might be trying to use me to achieve their own goals?
What advice do you have for recognizing when someone is trying to mislead me for their own benefit?

header: cxciv Have reasonable Views of Yourself and of your Affairs,
content: especially in the beginning of life. Every one has a high opinion of himself, especially those who have least ground for it. Every one dreams of his good-luck and thinks himself a wonder. Hope gives rise to extravagant promises which experience does not fulfil. Such idle imaginations merely serve as a well-spring of annoyance when disillusion comes with the true reality. The wise man anticipates such errors: he may always hope for the best. but he always expects the worst, so as to receive what comes with equanimity. True, It is wise to aim high so as to hit your mark, but not so high that you miss your mission at the very beginning of life. This correction of the ideas is necessary, because before experience comes expectation is sure to soar too high. The best panacea against folly is prudence. If a man knows the true sphere of his activity and position, the can reconcile his ideals with reality.
instructions: How can I balance my ambitions with the reality of my skills and circumstances as I start my journey in life?
What advice would you give to someone who often overestimates their potential and feels disillusioned when faced with reality?
What guidance can you offer for managing expectations and self-perception as I navigate the early stages of my career?
What insights can you share on developing a realistic outlook on self-worth and success as I embark on my new endeavors?

header: cxcv Know how to Appreciate.
content: There is none who cannot teach somebody something, and there is none so excellent but he is excelled. To know how to make use of every one is useful knowledge. Wise men appreciate all men, for they see the good in each and know how hard it is to make anything good. Fools depreciate all men, not recognising the good and selecting the bad.
instructions: What qualities should we look for in others to truly value their contributions?
How can we cultivate a mindset that recognizes the strengths and potential in everyone we encounter?
How can we shift our perspective to appreciate the unique strengths that each individual brings to the table, even in a diverse group?
How can we develop the ability to identify and celebrate the positive traits in people, even when they may have weaknesses?

header: cxcvi Know your ruling Star.
content: None so helpless as not to have one; if he is unlucky, that is because he does not know it. Some stand high in the favour of princes and potentates without knowing why or wherefore, except that good luck itself has granted them favour on easy terms, merely requiring them to aid it with a little exertion. Others find favour with the wise. One man is better received by one nation than by another, or is more welcome in one city than in another. He finds more luck in one office or position than another, and all this though his qualifications are equal or even identical. Luck shuffles the cards how and when she will. Let each man know his luck as well as his talents, for on this depends whether he loses or wins. Follow your guiding star and help it without mistaking any other for it, for that would be to miss the North, though its neighbour (the polestar) calls us to it with a voice of thunder.
instructions: How can I better understand my strengths and opportunities in life to maximize my potential for success?
How can I navigate life's uncertainties and align my actions with the opportunities that suit me best?
What strategies can I use to identify and embrace the unique circumstances or "luck" that may benefit me in my personal and professional journey?
How can I determine which paths in life align with my inherent traits and external circumstances to achieve the best outcomes?

header: cxcvii Do not carry Fools on your Back.
content: He that does not know a fool when he sees him is one himself: still more he that knows him but will not keep clear of him. They are dangerous company and ruinous confidants. Even though their own caution and others' care keeps them in bounds for a time, still at length they are sure to do or to say some foolishness which is all the greater for being kept so long in stock. They cannot help another's credit who have none of their own. They are most unlucky, which is the Nemesis of fools, and they have to pay for one thing or the other. There is only one thing which is not so bad about them, and this is that though they can be of no use to the wise, they can be of much use to them as signposts or as warnings.
instructions: What advice would you give on choosing friends and avoiding negative influences in one’s life?
How can one identify and distance themselves from toxic individuals who might hinder personal growth?
What insights can you provide on the potential consequences of associating with people who lack wisdom or sound judgment?
What should we be aware of when we encounter people who consistently act foolishly, and how can their behavior impact our own lives?

header: cxcviii Know how to transplant Yourself.
content: There are nations with whom one must cross their borders to make one's value felt, especially in great posts. Their native land is always a stepmother to great talents: envy flourishes there on its native soil, and they remember one's small beginnings rather than the greatness one has reached. A needle is appreciated that comes from one end of the world to the other, and a piece of painted glass might outvie the diamond in value if it comes from afar. Everything foreign is respected, partly because it comes from afar, partly because It is ready made and perfect. We have seen persons once the laughing-stock of their village and now the wonder of the whole world, honoured by their fellow-countrymen and by the foreigners [among whom they dwell]; by the latter because they come from afar, by the former because they are seen from afar. The statue on the altar is never reverenced by him who knew it as a trunk in the garden.
instructions: What advice can you give about how to advance one's career when faced with local envy and limitations?
How can one gain recognition and appreciation for their talents when they feel undervalued in their own community?
What insights can you share about the importance of seeking opportunities in new environments to showcase one's true potential?
How can someone effectively navigate the perception of their worth when their talents are overshadowed by their local background?

header: cxcix To find a proper Place by Merit, not by Presumption.
content: The true road to respect is through merit, and if industry accompany merit the path becomes shorter. Integrity alone is not sufficient, push and insistence is degrading, for things arrive by that means so besprinkled with dust that the discredit destroys reputation. The true way is the middle one, half-way between de-serving a place and pushing oneself into it.
instructions: What is the best approach to achieving recognition and success without compromising one's values?
How can one effectively navigate the balance between self-advocacy and genuine merit in a competitive environment?
How can one genuinely earn their place in society without resorting to arrogance or favoritism?
What principles should guide someone in their pursuit of advancement to ensure they are respected for their true abilities rather than for self-promotion?

header: cc Leave Something to wish for,
content: so as not to be miserable from very happiness. The body must respire and the soul aspire. If one possessed all, all would be disillusion and discontent. Even in knowledge there should be always something left to know in order to arouse curiosity and excite hope. Surfeits of happiness are fatal. In giving assistance it is a piece of policy not to satisfy entirely. If there is nothing left to desire, there is everything to fear, an unhappy state of happiness. When desire dies, fear is born.
instructions: Why is it important to leave room for desire and aspiration in our pursuit of happiness?
How can the constant pursuit of fulfillment lead to dissatisfaction and anxiety in our lives?
How can the balance between achieving our goals and maintaining a sense of longing contribute to a more enriching life experience?
How does the notion of desire influence our overall sense of fulfillment and contentment in life?

header: cci They are all Fools who seem so besides half the rest.
content: Folly arose with the world, and if there be any wisdom it is folly compared with the divine. But the greatest fool is he who thinks he is not one and all others are. To be wise It is not enough to seem wise, least of all to oneself. He knows who does not think that he knows, and he does not see who does not see that others see. Though all the world is full of fools, there is none that thinks himself one, or even suspects the fact.
instructions: What is true wisdom, and how can we recognize our own ignorance in a world filled with self-declared wise individuals?
How can we cultivate genuine self-awareness in a society where everyone believes they possess wisdom, while in reality, they may be blinded by their own folly?
Is it possible that our perception of wisdom is just a reflection of our own ego, and how can we navigate through the illusions of wisdom in ourselves and others?
How can we discern true intelligence in ourselves and others when society often promotes a false sense of superiority that obscures our understanding of folly?

header: ccii Words and Deeds make the Perfect Man.
content: One should speak well and act honourably: the one is an excellence of the head, the other of the heart, and both arise from nobility of soul. Words are the shadows of deeds; the former are feminine, the latter masculine. It is more important to be renowned than to convey renown. Speech is easy, action hard. Actions are the stuff of life, words its frippery. Eminent deeds endure, striking words pass away. Actions are the fruit of thought; if this is wise, they are effective.
instructions: What qualities should a person embody to truly achieve greatness in life?
How can one balance eloquence in speech with the integrity of their actions to embody true character?
What does it mean to be a person of substance in a world filled with superficiality?
How can we distinguish between genuine intentions and mere words in our interactions with others?

header: cciii Know the great Men of your Age.
content: They are not many. There is one Phœnix in the whole world, one great general, one perfect orator, one true philosopher in a century, a really illustrious king in several. Mediocrities are as numerous as they are worth-less: eminent greatness is rare in every respect, since it needs complete perfection, and the higher the species the more difficult is the highest rank in it. Many have claimed the title "Great," like Cæsar and Alexander, but in vain, for without great deeds the title is a mere breath of air. There have been few Senecas, and fame records but one Apelles.
instructions: What is your perspective on the rarity of truly exceptional individuals in history?
How do you define greatness, and what qualities do you believe distinguish truly remarkable individuals from the rest?
What do you think separates legendary figures in history from those who are merely famous for their titles?
What are the characteristics that define a truly remarkable individual in your view?

header: cciv Attempt easy Tasks as if they were difficult, and difficult as if they were easy.
content: In the one case that confidence may not fall asleep, in the other that it may not be dismayed. For a thing to remain undone nothing more is needed than to think it done. On the other hand, patient industry overcomes impossibilities. Great undertakings are not to be brooded over, lest their difficulty when seen causes despair.
instructions: How can we cultivate confidence and tackle challenges without becoming overwhelmed by their complexities?
What strategies can we adopt to approach daunting projects while maintaining a sense of optimism and motivation?
What mindset should we adopt to effectively manage our fears when facing new and challenging tasks?
What approaches can we take to ensure that we stay engaged and focused on our goals, especially when confronting tasks that initially seem insurmountable?

header: ccv Know how to play the Card of Contempt.
content: It is a shrewd way of getting things you want, by affecting to depreciate them: generally they are not to be had when sought for, but fall into one's hands when one is not looking for them. As all mundane things are but shadows of the things eternal, they share with shadows this quality, that they flee from him who follows them and follow him that flees from them. Contempt is besides the most subtle form of revenge. It is a fixed rule with the wise never to defend themselves with the pen. For such defence always leaves a stain, and does more to glorify one's opponent than to punish his offence. It is a trick of the worthless to stand forth as opponents of great men, so as to win notoriety by a roundabout way, which they would never do by the straight road of merit. There are many we would not have heard of if their eminent opponents had not taken notice of them. There is no revenge like oblivion, through which they are buried in the dust of their unworthiness. Audacious persons hope to make themselves eternally famous by setting fire to one of the wonders of the world and of the ages. The art of reproving scandal is to take no notice of it, to combat it damages our own case; even if credited it causes discredit, and is a source of satisfaction to our opponent, for this shadow of a stain dulls the lustre of our fame even if it cannot altogether deaden it.
instructions: How should one handle criticism and negativity from others without letting it affect their reputation or dignity?
What strategies can one employ to navigate conflict or challenges posed by rivals or critics without diminishing their own stature or credibility?
What are the most effective ways to rise above petty attacks or provocations from those who seek attention at our expense?
What are the best ways to maintain personal integrity and poise when faced with insincere challenges from those seeking to undermine you?

header: ccvi Know that there are vulgar Natures everywhere,
content: even in Corinth itself, even in the highest families. Every one may try the experiment within his own gates. But there is also such a thing as vulgar opposition to vulgarity, which is worse. This special kind shares all the qualities of the common kind, just as bits of a broken glass: but this kind is still more pernicious; it speaks folly, blames impertinently, is a disciple of ignorance, a patron of folly, and past master of scandal; you need not notice what it says, still less what it thinks. It is important to know vulgarity in order to avoid it, whether it is subjective or objective. For all folly is vulgarity, and the vulgar consist of fools.
instructions: Why is it important to recognize and avoid both common vulgarity and the more insidious forms of opposition to it?
How can one differentiate between genuine wisdom and the mere rejection of ignorance that is itself ignorant?
What are the dangers of engaging with or responding to those who express a superficial disdain for vulgarity without understanding its true nature?
How can we effectively navigate social interactions when faced with both outright vulgarity and the more subtle forms of pretentiousness that reject it?

header: ccvii Be Moderate.
content: One has to consider the chance of a mischance. The impulses of the passions cause prudence to slip, and there is the risk of ruin. A moment of wrath or of pleasure carries you on farther than many hours of calm, and often a short diversion may put a whole life to shame. The cunning of others uses such moments of temptation to search the recesses of the mind: they use such thumbscrews as are wont to test the best caution. Moderation serves as a counterplot, especially in sudden emergencies. Much thought is needed to prevent a passion taking the bit in the teeth, and he is doubly wise who is wise on horseback. He who knows the danger may with care pursue his journey. Light as a word may appear to him who throws it out, it may import much to him that hears it and ponders on it.
instructions: How can I effectively manage my emotions during stressful situations to avoid making regrettable decisions?
What strategies can I employ to maintain balance and restraint when faced with powerful temptations or emotional upheavals?
What advice can you offer on how to stay level-headed and composed when confronted with unexpected challenges or intense feelings?
In moments of extreme passion or pressure, how can I remind myself to think clearly and act wisely instead of letting my emotions take control?

header: ccviii Do not die of the Fools' Disease.
content: The wise generally die after they have lost their reason: fools before they have found it. To die of the fools' disease is to die of too much thought. Some die because they think and feel too much: others live because they do not think and feel: these are fools because they do not die of sorrow, the others because they do. A fool is he that dies of too much knowledge: thus some die because they are too knowing, others because they are not knowing enough. Yet though many die like fools, few die fools.
instructions: What are the consequences of overthinking and excessive knowledge on our well-being?
What insights can you provide about the relationship between wisdom and ignorance in the context of emotional suffering?
How can striving for knowledge and understanding both enrich and burden our lives?
How do you view the balance between knowledge and emotional resilience in the pursuit of a fulfilling life?

header: ccix Keep Yourself free from common Follies.
content: This is a special stroke of policy. They are of special power because they are general, so that many who would not be led away by any individual folly cannot escape the universal failing. Among these are to be counted the common prejudice that any one is satisfied with his fortune, however great, or unsatisfied with his intellect, however poor it is. Or again, that each, being discontented with his own lot, envies that of others; or further, that persons of to-day praise the things of yesterday, and those here the things there. Everything past seems best and everything distant is more valued. He is as great a fool that laughs at all as he that weeps at all.
instructions: What insights can you share about the common pitfalls of human nature and how they affect our perception of ourselves and others?
How can we protect ourselves from the universal tendencies of comparison and dissatisfaction that seem to affect everyone, regardless of their individual circumstances?
How can we navigate the common biases and judgments that distort our view of success and happiness in our lives?

In a world where social media often amplifies feelings of envy and discontent, how can we cultivate a mindset that appreciates our own circumstances without falling prey to the common habit of comparing ourselves to others?

header: ccx Know how to play the Card of Truth.
content: ’Tis dangerous, yet a good man cannot avoid speaking it. But great skill is needed here: the most expert doctors of the soul pay great attention to the means of sweetening the pill of truth. For when it deals with the destroying of illusion it is the quintessence of bitterness. A pleasant manner has here an opportunity for a display of skill: with the same truth it can flatter one and fell another to the ground. Matters of to-day should be treated as if they were long past. For those who can understand a word is sufficient, and if it does not suffice, it is a case for silence. Princes must not be cured with bitter draughts; it is therefore desirable in their case to gild the pill of disillusion.
instructions: How can one effectively communicate difficult truths without causing offense or harm to others?
What strategies can one use to address uncomfortable realities while maintaining positive relationships with others?
What techniques can help soften the impact of harsh realities when sharing them with someone in a position of power or influence?
How can we convey uncomfortable truths in a way that encourages understanding rather than defensiveness?

header: ccxi In Heaven all is bliss:
content: in Hell all misery. On earth, between the two, both one thing and the other. We stand between the two extremes, and therefore share both. Fate varies: all is not good luck nor all mischance. This world is merely zero: by itself it is of no value, but with Heaven in Front of it, it means much. Indifference at its ups and downs is prudent, nor is there any novelty for the wise. Our life gets as complicated as a comedy as it goes on, but the complications get gradually resolved: see that the curtain comes down on a good dénoûment.
instructions: How can one find meaning and balance in life amidst the extremes of fortune and misfortune?
What insights can you share about the interplay between happiness and suffering in our earthly existence?
How does the nature of our experiences shape our understanding of life's ups and downs?
What perspective can you offer on how to navigate the complexities and uncertainties of life while maintaining a sense of hope and resolution?

header: ccxii Keep to Yourself the final Touches of your Art.
content: This is a maxim of the great masters who pride themselves on this subtlety in teaching their pupils: one must always remain superior, remain master. One must teach an art artfully. The source of knowledge need not be pointed out no more than that of giving. By this means a man preserves the respect and the dependence of others. In amusing and teaching you must keep to the rule: keep up expectation and advance in perfection. To keep a reserve is a great rule for life and for success, especially for those in high place.
instructions: How can one effectively teach others without losing their own authority or leaving them feeling overly dependent?
What are the key principles one should follow to ensure that their mastery and expertise remain respected while helping others grow?
What strategies can someone use to maintain an air of mystery and intrigue while sharing their skills or knowledge with others?
What techniques can be employed to enhance one's teaching approach while preserving a sense of personal mastery and encouraging self-reliance in learners?

header: ccxiii Know how to Contradict.
content: A chief means of finding things out—to embarrass others without being embarrassed. The true thumbscrew, it brings the passions into play. Tepid incredulity acts as an emetic on secrets. It is the key to a locked-up breast, and with great subtlety makes a double trial of both mind and will. A sly depreciation of another's mysterious word scents out the profoundest secrets; some sweet bait brings them into the mouth till they fall from the tongue and are caught in the net of astute deceit. [paragraph continues] By reserving your attention the other becomes less attentive, and lets his thoughts appear while otherwise his heart were inscrutable. An affected doubt is the subtlest picklock that curiosity can use to find out what it wants to know. Also in learning it is a subtle plan of the pupil to contradict the master, who thereupon takes pains to explain the truth more thoroughly and with more force, so that a moderate contradiction produces complete instruction.
instructions: How can one effectively uncover secrets or gain deeper insights through conversation?
What techniques can one use to engage in meaningful discussions that lead to a greater understanding of complex ideas?
What are some strategies to encourage open dialogue and provoke deeper thought in others during a conversation?
What role does gentle disagreement play in enhancing learning and revealing hidden truths during discussions?

header: ccxiv Do not turn one Blunder into two.
content: It is quite usual to commit four others in order to remedy one, or to excuse one piece of impertinence by still another. Folly is either related to, or identical with the family of Lies, for in both cases it needs many to support one. The worst of a bad case is having to fight it, and worse than the ill itself is not being able to conceal it. The annuity of one failing serves to support many others. A wise man may make one slip but never two, and that only in running, not while standing still.
instructions: How should one handle mistakes or missteps to avoid compounding their consequences?
What advice can you give for maintaining integrity when dealing with personal shortcomings?
What is the best approach to managing errors without letting them snowball into further problems?
How can one prevent a single wrong action from leading to a series of further mistakes?

header: ccxv Watch him that acts on Second Thoughts.
content: It is a device of business men to put the opponent off his guard before attacking him, and thus to conquer by being defeated: they dissemble their desire so as to attain it. They put themselves second so as to come out first in the final spurt. This method rarely fails if it is not noticed. Let therefore the attention never sleep when the intention is so wide awake. And if the other puts himself second so to hide his plan, put yourself first to discover it. Prudence can discern the artifices which such a man uses, and notices the pretexts he puts forward to gain his ends. He aims at one thing to get another: then he turns round smartly and fires straight at his target. It is well to know what you grant him, and at times it is desirable to give him to understand that you understand.
instructions: What strategies should I use to navigate negotiations with someone who seems to be concealing their true intentions?
How can I effectively evaluate and respond to someone's hidden motives in a competitive situation?
How can I stay one step ahead of someone who seems to be hiding their true agenda during a discussion or deal?
What tips do you have for uncovering someone’s hidden plans when they seem to be playing a strategic game in our interactions?

header: ccxvi Be Expressive.
content: This depends not only on the clearness but also on the vivacity of your thoughts. Some have an easy conception but a hard labour, for without clearness the children of the mind, thoughts and judgments, cannot be brought into the world. Many have a capacity like that of vessels with a large mouth and a small vent. Others again say more than they think. Resolution for the will, expression for the thought: two great gifts. Plausible minds are applauded: yet confused ones are often venerated just because they are not understood, and at times obscurity is convenient if you wish to avoid vulgarity; yet how shall the audience understand one that connects no definite idea with what he says?
instructions: How can one effectively communicate complex ideas without losing clarity and connection with the audience?
What are the key qualities that differentiate impactful communication from mere noise in conversation?
What role does the ability to articulate thoughts clearly and expressively play in influencing and connecting with others?
What strategies can we adopt to ensure our thoughts are not only expressed clearly but also resonate with and engage our audience effectively?

header: ccxvii Neither Love nor Hate, for ever
content: Trust the friends of to-day as if they will be enemies to-morrow, and that of the worst kind. As this happens in reality, let it happen in your precaution. Do not put weapons in the hand for deserters from friendship to wage war with. On the other hand, leave the door of reconciliation open for enemies, and if it is also the gate of generosity so much the more safe. The vengeance of long ago is at times the torment of to-day, and the joy over the ill we have done is turned to grief,
instructions: How can we navigate friendships and rivalries in a world where trust is so fragile?
What are your thoughts on how to maintain a balance between forgiveness and self-protection in relationships?
What advice do you have for safeguarding oneself emotionally in relationships where loyalty and betrayal seem to coexist?
How can we cultivate resilience in our relationships while remaining open to the potential for reconciliation, even with those who have hurt us?

header: ccxviii Never act from Obstinacy but from Knowledge.
content: All obstinacy is an excrescence of the mind, a grandchild of passion which never did anything right. There are persons who make a war out of everything, real banditti of intercourse. All that they undertake must end in victory; they do not know how to get on in peace. Such men are fatal when they rule and govern, for they make government rebellion, and enemies out of those whom they ought to regard as children. They try to effect everything with strategy and treat it as the fruit of their skill. But when others have recognised their perverse humour all revolt against them and learn to overturn their chimerical plans, and they succeed in nothing but only heap up a mass of troubles, since everything serves to increase their disappointment. They have a head turned and a heart spoilt. Nothing can be done with such monsters except to flee from them, even to the Antipodes, where the savagery is easier to bear than their loathsome nature.
instructions: Why is it important to distinguish between acting out of passion and acting based on knowledge in leadership and decision-making?
What are the dangers of being inflexible in one's beliefs or strategies when dealing with others in positions of authority?
What are the consequences of allowing stubbornness to dominate one's approach in personal relationships and social interactions?
How can an obsession with winning influence a leader's ability to foster collaboration and maintain harmony within a team?

header: ccxix Do not pass for a Hypocrite,
content: though such men are indispensable nowadays. Be considered rather prudent than astute. Sincerity in behaviour pleases all, though not all can show it in their own affairs. Sincerity should not degenerate into simplicity nor sagacity into cunning. Be rather respected as wise than feared as sly. The open-hearted are loved but deceived. The great art consists in disclosing what is thought to be deceit. In the golden age simplicity flourished, in these days of iron cunning. 'The reputation of being a man who knows what he has to do is honourable and inspires confidence, but to be considered a hypocrite is deceptive and arouses mistrust.
instructions: What is your perspective on the balance between sincerity and strategy in interpersonal relationships?
How do you define the qualities of a wise person in today's complex social landscape?
How can one navigate modern social dynamics without sacrificing authenticity for the sake of personal advancement?
In a world where social interactions often involve manipulation, how can one maintain integrity while still being effective in pursuing their goals?

header: ccxx If you cannot clothe Yourself in Lionskin use Foxpelt.
content: To follow the times is to lead them. He that gets what he wants never loses his reputation. Cleverness when force will not do. One way or another, the king's highway of valour or the bypath of cunning. Skill has effected more than force, and astuteness has conquered courage more often than the other way. When you cannot get a thing then is the time to despise it.
instructions: How can one achieve success and maintain their reputation in a world where strength and power are often valued over cunning and strategy?
What should one do when faced with challenges that require adaptation and resourcefulness instead of brute strength?
How can one effectively navigate situations where direct confrontation is not possible, and when should one choose cleverness over aggression?
In a competitive environment where direct confrontation is often discouraged, how can one leverage wit and strategy to achieve their goals without compromising their integrity?

header: ccxxi Do not seize Occasions to embarrass Yourself or Others.
content: There are some men stumbling-blocks of good manners either for themselves or for others: they are always on the point of some stupidity. You meet with them easily and part from them uneasily. A hundred annoyances a day is nothing to them. Their humour always strokes the wrong way since they contradict all and every. They put on the judgment cap wrong side foremost and thus condemn all. Yet the greatest test of others' patience and prudence are just those who do no good and speak ill of all. There are many monsters in the wide realm of Indecorum.
instructions: How can we navigate social situations without inadvertently causing discomfort or frustration for ourselves and others?
What advice can you offer on how to maintain composure and grace in the face of individuals who often disrupt social harmony?
What insights can you share about managing interactions with people who consistently create tension and conflict in social settings?
What strategies can we employ to avoid engaging with individuals who consistently create awkwardness in social situations?

header: ccxxii Reserve is proof of Prudence.
content: The tongue is a wild beast; once let loose it is difficult to chain. It is the pulse of the soul by which wise men judge of its health: by this pulse a careful observer feels every movement of the heart. The worst is that he who should be most reserved is the least. The sage saves himself from worries and embarrassments, and shows his mastery over himself. He goes his way carefully, a Janus for impartiality, an Argus for watchfulness. Truly Momus had better placed the eyes in the hand than the window in the breast.
instructions: How important is self-control in our communication and interactions with others?
How can we navigate the complexities of expressing our thoughts without losing control over our words?
What role does discretion play in demonstrating wisdom and maintaining social harmony?
How can someone cultivate the ability to exercise restraint in their speech while still expressing their true thoughts and feelings?

header: ccxxiii Be not Eccentric,
content: neither from affectation nor carelessness. [paragraph continues] Many have some remarkable and individual quality leading to eccentric actions. These are more defects than excellent differences. And just as some are known for some special ugliness, so these for something repellant in their outward behaviour. Such eccentricities simply serve as trademarks through their atrocious singularity: they cause either derision or ill-will.
instructions: Why is it important to avoid being eccentric in our behaviors and actions?
How can we differentiate between being unique and simply being eccentric, without falling into the pitfalls of negative attention?
Is there a fine line between expressing individuality and coming across as socially inappropriate, and how can we navigate that space without attracting negativity?
What are the consequences of acting in unusual ways that might draw negative reactions from others?

header: ccxxiv Never take Things against the Grain,
content: no matter how they come. Everything has a smooth and a seamy side, and the best weapon wounds if taken by the blade, while the enemy's spear may be our best protection if taken by the staff. Many things cause pain which would cause pleasure if you regarded their advantages. There is a favourable and an unfavourable side to everything, the cleverness consists in finding out the favourable. The same thing looks quite different in another light; look at it therefore on its best side and do not exchange good for evil. Thus it haps that many find joy, many grief, in everything. This remark is a great protection against the frowns of fortune, and a weighty rule of life for all times and all conditions.
instructions: How can I maintain a positive perspective in challenging situations?
What should I consider when facing obstacles or setbacks in my life?
How can I effectively navigate difficult circumstances and find opportunities within them?
How can I transform my perception of negative experiences into opportunities for growth?

header: ccxxv Know your chief Fault.
content: There lives none that has not in himself' a counterbalance to his most conspicuous merit: if this be nourished by desire it may grow to be a tyrant. Commence war against it, summoning prudence as your ally, and the first thing to do is the public manifesto, for an evil once known is soon conquered, especially when the one afflicted regards it in the same light as the onlookers. To be master of oneself one should know oneself. If the chief imperfection surrender, the rest will come to an end.
instructions: What strategies can I use to overcome my greatest weaknesses and become a better person?
How can I gain a better understanding of my flaws in order to improve myself effectively?
What steps should I take to identify and address my most significant personal shortcomings?
What are the key qualities I need to develop in order to gain mastery over my personal shortcomings and achieve self-awareness?

header: ccxxvi Take care to be Obliging.
content: Most talk and act, not as they are, but as they are obliged. To persuade people of ill is easy for any, since the ill is easily credited even when at times it is incredible. The best we have depends on the opinion of others. Some are satisfied if they have right on their side, but that is not enough, for it must be assisted by energy. To oblige persons often costs little and helps much. With words you may purchase deeds. In this great house of the world there is no chamber so hid that it may not be wanted one day in the year, and then you would miss it however little is its worth. Every one speaks of a subject according to his feelings.
instructions: How important is it to consider others' opinions in our interactions and relationships?
What strategies can we use to effectively persuade others while maintaining good relationships?
How can being accommodating and respectful in our communication impact our personal and professional connections?
What role does kindness play in shaping how we are perceived by others in our daily lives?

header: ccxxvii Do not be the Slave of First Impressions.
content: Some marry the very first account they hear: all others must live with them as concubines. But as a lie has swift legs, the truth with them can find no lodging. We should neither satisfy our will with the first object nor our mind with the first proposition: for that were superficial. Many are like new casks who keep the scent of the first liquor they hold, be it good or bad. If this superficiality becomes known, it becomes fatal, for it then gives opportunity for cunning mischief; the ill-minded hasten to colour the mind of the credulous. Always therefore leave room for a second hearing. Alexander always kept one ear for the other side. Wait for the second or even third edition of news. To be the slave of your impressions argues want of capacity, and is not far from being the slave of your passions.
instructions: How can I avoid being misled by my first impressions in important decisions?
What strategies can I employ to ensure that my understanding of a situation is well-rounded and not influenced solely by initial perceptions?
